name: ASB 102: Intro to Cultural Anthropology (2021 Fall)
syllabus_body:
*THIS CONTENT IS PROTECTED AND MAY NOT BE SHARED, UPLOADED, SOLD, OR DISTRIBUTED.*

To print: MAC users press "⌘" + "P". PC users press "CTRL" + "P".

Note: this syllabus is not a contract.  It is subject to further change or revision, to best realize the educational goals of the course. Revisions will be announced in class or in course materials online with appropriate prior notice.

ASB 102: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology

 

Land Statement: The ASU Tempe campus was built on the homelands of the Akimel O'odham and Piipash peoples. We acknowledge these people, their ancestors, their descendants, and the land itself. This statement acknowledges that colonialism is not a past event, but an ongoing process of which we are a part.

 

Instructor: Dr. Rhian Stotts

Office: West Hall 166

Contact Info: rstotts@asu.edu

Office Hours (on Zoom): Tuesdays 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM (or by appointment): https://asu.zoom.us/j/3310101443 

 

Teaching Assistant: Marcos C. Martinez

Contact Info: mcmart29@asu.edu 

Virtual Office Hours: Thursdays 3:00-4:30 PM (or by appointment) https://asu.zoom.us/j/89874373286

 

Course Description:

This course introduces the basic principles of sociocultural anthropology, a discipline concerned with the origins, development, and diversity of human culture and society.  Using illustrative materials from a variety of cultures, we will explore variation in human behaviors and beliefs and consider some of the ways anthropologists have attempted to account for that variation.  A particular concern in the course will be the manner in which global processes of economic, political, and social change intersect with the everyday lives of local people.  A broader goal of the course is to introduce students to the way anthropologists think about their subject matter. 

 

Class Meeting:

Tuesdays and Thursdays 1:30 PM - 2:45 PM

Bateman Physical Sciences Center H (PSH) 150

 

Course Goals/Learning Outcomes:

By successfully completing this course, students will be able to:

  • Discuss important concepts of cultural anthropology (ethnographic fieldwork, language, religion, race, ethnicity, gender, kinship, political economy, migration, globalization, subsistence, environmental sustainability, health, etc.)
  • Describe and apply some of the methods, theories, and procedures anthropologists use to study cultures
  • Recognize similarities and differences in human cultures
  • Critique your own culture and cultural practices
  • Develop and apply critical thinking and writing skills
  • Demonstrate an appreciation for the richness and variety of human cultures across the world

 

Required Course Texts/ Readings:

  • The primary textbook for this course is Perspectives: An Open Invitation to Cultural Anthropology. This is an open-access textbook produced by the Society for Anthropology in Community Colleges section of the American Anthropological Association. Open-access means that the textbook is free and is available online thus you are not required to purchase this textbook. All of your required readings from this textbook are already available on the online course platform. Additional readings are also available on the course platform.

 

Course Format:

This three-credit, lower division class is taught in-person. Each class period will feature lectures and in-class activities. There are seven modules in this course. The first module introduces the field of anthropology and the main concepts that will be discussed throughout the course. Module 2-6 each focus on a subset of topics that are of particular interest to anthropologists. The final module will then bring together the course material to discuss how anthropological work is used outside of academia. Each module contains required readings and videos that students will be expected to complete independently. Class discussions and activities will occur during our synchronous meetings. Students will be assessed on their understanding of the course material through quizzes, random mini-assignments, and the Applying Anthropology assignments.

The modules for the course are as follows:

  • Module 1: Introduction to Anthropology
  • Module 2: Language, Worldview, and Religion
  • Module 3: Kinship, Gender, and Race
  • Module 4: Politics, Economics, and Migration
  • Module 5: Subsistence and Sustainability
  • Module 6: Health and Illness
  • Module 7: The Value of Anthropology

 

Coursework/Assignments:

Note: Please read this section of the syllabus very carefully!

Final grades for the course will be assigned on basis of the assignments described below. Detailed step-by-step instructions for each assignment are posted on the course site. Due dates are posted in the Course Schedule.

1. Quizzes (25% of the total)

There are eight total quizzes available in this course. 

The first quiz is a “Readiness Quiz,” a quiz required to open the rest of the course content. This quiz will cover the material presented in Course Introduction Resources as well as any of the information presented under the tabs “Syllabus” or ASU Course Policies. You may retake the Readiness Quiz as many times as you like until the due date to receive full points. After the due date, you still must take the Readiness Quiz to unlock the course modules, but you will not receive points nor be able to re-take the quiz to acquire more points.

The seven modules will also have a quiz. You must complete 6 of the module quizzes. If you complete all seven quizzes, your lowest module quiz score will be dropped. To prepare for the quiz, complete the readings, view the lectures and videos within each module, and come to our synchronous class meetings. These quizzes are open-book and open-lecture, but they will be timed and only available for 60 minutes. Therefore, it will be difficult to find all the right answers if you have not studied the content beforehand. See General Guidelines for Taking Notes and Completing Quizzes for more information on quizzes.

Unlike the Readiness Quiz, you may NOT re-take any of the module quizzes for a better grade. The goal of these quizzes is simply to ensure you have comprehended the required material for that particular module. All quizzes must be submitted by 11:59 pm on the date marked in the course schedule.

  1. Mini-Assignment Activities (25% of total)

Randomly, throughout the semester, students will be asked to submit check-ins to ensure they are keeping up with course material and so we can gauge student understanding of concepts. Some examples of what these mini-assignments could be include the reading guides or documentary guides provided for each reading and video, results of small-group activity work from synchronous meetings, or reflections on course material. These mini-assignments will be primarily evaluated on the basis of participation. The two lowest in-class activity grades will be dropped (essentially allowing two unexcused absences).

  1. Applying Anthropology Assignments (50% of total)

Throughout the course there are assignments designed to get you thinking like an anthropologist. Students are required to complete the Sub-culture Selection and Reflection assignments. Students are also required to complete two of the remaining four assignments based on their interest and schedule. 

  • Sub-culture Selection (required, 25 points)
  • Background Research (optional, 75 points)
  • Auto-ethnography (optional, 75 points)
  • Participant Observation (optional, 75 points)
  • Interviews (optional, 75 points)
  • Reflection (required, 50 points)

Specific detailed instructions and grading rubrics for each assignment are located in the course modules. All assignments are due by 11:59 pm on the date indicated in the course schedule.

Please Note: For your own protection, you should keep a copy of everything you hand in, and you should keep your graded assignments at least until grades are finalized at the end of the semester, in the event you wish to contest any grades.

Extra Credit

Extra credit of up to 2% of the final grade will be available throughout the semester.

 

Late Work

This course is set up to allow you flexibility by allowing you to miss one module quiz, two mini-assignments, and only being required to complete four of the six Applying Anthropology assignments, However, I recognize that more flexibility may be required. All first time requests for a 24-hour extension of quizzes or assignments will be granted. Additional requests or extension requests beyond 24 hours will be determined on a case by case basis. Please reach out. Most additional extension requests are granted.

Note that we do not require an explanation or documentation for a first time request. However, an emailed extension request is required. You cannot simply turn in a late assignment without communication.  

*Arizona does not follow daylight savings time.  If you are not located in Arizona, is your responsibility to determine the appropriate time zone conversion for timely submission of quizzes and assignments*

Please note:  If there is a system-wide outage for longer than an hour after 5 PM on the day an assignment is due, you will not be punished for not turning in material on time, but will be required to turn it in by 11:59 pm the following day. You can confirm system-wide Canvas outages at https://uto.asu.edu/system-health (Links to an external site.). If MyASU is down, Canvas can still be accessed at asu.instructure.com.  

 

Attendance:

Attendance is not graded, however attendance may be tracked as may completion of the lectures, readings, and other coursework. You will be contacted if it appears that you are not participating to ensure you can be successful in the course.

While attendance is not graded, active participation in the course is expected. This means that students should attend our in-person meetings. However, if you are experiencing any symptoms of COVID-19 (e.g. fever or chills, cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, new loss of taste or smell, sore throat, congestion or runny nose, nausea or vomiting, diarrhea), please DO NOT attend class (and please consider being tested for COVID-19: https://devilsdropoff.asu.edu/)

 

Pre-Deadline Feedback:

We are invested in making sure students can get the help they need to succeed. Students who wish to gain feedback on their Applying Anthropology assignments before the due date can do so by emailing Dr. Stotts and their assigned TA a draft of their assignment with a polite request for feedback. The draft must be received 2 business days before the deadline. So, if the deadline is Sunday at 11:59 pm, then the cut-off time to send your email is Wednesday at 5pm. You may just receive feedback via email or you may receive a request to set up a Skype meeting.

Please note, this is not an opportunity for us to "pregrade" your assignment, but rather to discuss whether you are on the right track content-wise. We may recommend that you make an appointment with the writing center before you hand your assignment in on the due date to get assistance with grammar and syntax.

When submitting your request for feedback, it is most useful to provide us with specific questions like: "Is #3 asking us to include [this...] or [that...]?" or "I struggled with [this...], can you please focus your feedback on that area? Asking "Can you look over my paper to see if it’s okay?" is acceptable but will likely generate less specific feedback. 

Do not hesitate to ask any question about the assignment, but know that solicitations to 'look over' all or part of your assignment will be turned down unless it is handled in the manner stated above. More general questions about assignments should be posted to the Hallway Conversations board.

 

Grade Reviews and Disputes:

If you would like to dispute the answer to a specific quiz question, please email your TA. In your email, you must list (1) the exact wording of the question, (2) the exact wording of the "correct” answer as marked in Canvas, (3), the exact wording of the answer you gave, and (4) justification for the answer you gave with specific reference to the course reading or material which justifies the answer. Each quiz has a different selection of questions presented in a random order that is different for each student, so telling us that you disagree with Question 3 will not suffice. Grade review for quiz questions is available up to five calendar days after the due date of the quiz has passed. That is, if a quiz due date is Friday at 11:59 pm, you have until Wednesday at 11:59 pm to contact your TA via email.

If you dispute the grade you receive for a mini-assignment or an Applying Anthropology assignment, you should email your TA with questions regarding your grade. Your TA may request that you set up a Skype meeting to discuss the grade in more detail. If, after the meeting with the TA, you still dispute the grade, you can request to have Dr. Stotts regrade the assignment. If you request re-grading, the second grade will stand, regardless of whether it is higher or lower than the original grade (i.e., your grade may go down as well as up!). You may request re-grading up to five calendar days after an assignment has been returned; in the fast pace of this course, re-grading requests after this time cannot be considered. That is, if an assignment grade is entered into the gradebook on Tuesday at noon, you have until Friday at noon to request a meeting with your TA via email.

 

Final Grades:

Final letter grades will be based on the following percentage breakdown:

A- / A / A+ 89.5-92.4 / 92.5-97.4 / 97.5-100 Excellent
B- / B / B+ 79.5-82.4 / 82.5-87.4 / 87.5-89.4 Good
C / C+ 69.5-77.4 / 77.5-79.4 Fair
D 59.5-69.4 Passing
E ≤ 59.4 Failure
XE Failure due to Academic Dishonesty
EN Failure due to Having Never Participated

 

Incompletes:

A mark of "I" (incomplete) is given by the instructor only in the most extraordinary (and documented) circumstances, and when you have completed at least 80% of the course and are otherwise doing acceptable work (i.e., have a passing grade) but are unable to complete the course because of illness or other conditions beyond your control. You are required to arrange with the instructor for the completion of the course requirements. You need to apply as early as possible and use the Request for Grade of Incomplete form (http://students.asu.edu/forms/incomplete-grade-request).

 

Final Letter Grade Appeals:

ASU has formal and informal channels to appeal a grade. If you wish to appeal any grading decisions, please see http://catalog.asu.edu/appeal.

 

Student Standards:

ASU expects and requires its students to act with honesty, integrity, and respect. Required behavior standards are listed in the Student Code of Conduct and Student Disciplinary Procedures, Computer, Internet, and Electronic Communications policy, ASU Student Academic Integrity Policy, and outlined by the Office of Student Rights & Responsibilities. Anyone in violation of these policies is subject to sanctions.

The Office of Student Rights and Responsibilities accepts incident reports from students, faculty, staff, or other persons who believe that a student or a student organization may have violated the Student Code of Conduct.  Students are required to read and act in accordance with university and Arizona Board of Regents policies, including: The ABOR Code of Conduct: Arizona Board of Regents Policies 5-301 through 5-308: https://students.asu.edu/srr

 

Expected classroom behavior:

Students are entitled to receive instruction free from interference by other members of the class. An instructor may withdraw a student from the course when the student's behavior disrupts the educational process per Instructor Withdrawal of a Student for Disruptive Classroom Behavior.

 

Communication:

This course uses a discussion board called "Hallway Conversations" for general questions about the course. Prior to posting a question, please check the syllabus, announcements, and existing posts. If you do not find an answer, post your question. You are encouraged to respond to the questions of your classmates. Please email your instructor if your question relates to a personal grade.

ASU email is an official means of communication among students, faculty, and staff. All instructor correspondence will be sent to your ASU email account. Students are expected to read and act upon email in a timely fashion. Students bear the responsibility of missed messages and should check their ASU-assigned email regularly.

All communications should be professional and succinct.   You should be in the habit of checking your ASU email regularly as you will not only receive important information about your class(es), but other important university updates and information. You are solely responsible for reading and responding if necessary to any information communicated via email.  For help with your email contact the help desk. 

Expect faculty to respond to emails between 9am and 5pm, Monday through Friday. within 2 business days. TAs will respond within 1 business day. Be specific about the subject of the email in the mail subject heading, Additionally, all emails need to do the following:

  • Use a proper salutation for me and your TAs (Hello, Dr. Stotts, or Dear TA...)
  • List which class you are taking.
  • Use complete sentences, capitalization, and punctuation. Check your grammar and spelling.
  • Closing: You should close the email with a salutation and your full name as it appears in Canvas. Also, it is not always necessary, but if you are making a request, a “thank you” is appropriate.

 

Policy against threatening behavior:

All incidents and allegations of violent or threatening conduct by an ASU student        (whether on-or off campus) must be reported to the ASU Police Department (ASU PD) and the Office of the Dean of Students.  If either office determines that the behavior poses or has posed a serious threat to personal safety or to the welfare of the campus, the student will not be permitted to return to campus or reside in any ASU residence hall      until an appropriate threat assessment has been completed and, if necessary, conditions for return are imposed. ASU PD, the Office of the Dean of Students, and other appropriate

 

Academic Integrity:

Academic honesty is expected of all students in all examinations, papers, laboratory work, academic transactions and records. The possible sanctions include, but are not limited to, appropriate grade penalties, course failure (indicated on the transcript as a grade of E), course failure due to academic dishonesty (indicated on the transcript as a grade of XE), loss of registration privileges, disqualification and dismissal.  For more information, see http://provost.asu.edu/academicintegrity.

If you fail to meet the standards of academic integrity in any of the criteria listed on the university policy website, sanctions will be imposed by the instructor, school, and/or dean. Academic dishonesty includes borrowing ideas without proper citation, copying others’ work (including information posted on the internet), allowing others to copy your work (including posting reading guides, quiz questions, and assignments to websites like CourseHero and StuDocu), and failing to turn in your own work for group projects. Please be aware that if you follow an argument closely, even if it is not directly quoted, you must provide a citation to the publication, including the author, date and page number. If you directly quote a source, you must use quotation marks and provide the same sort of citation for each quoted sentence or phrase.  You may work with other students on assignments, however, all writing that you turn in must be done independently.  If you have any doubt about whether the form of cooperation you contemplate is acceptable, ask the TA or the instructor in advance of turning in an assignment. Please be aware that the work of all students submitted electronically will be scanned using TurnItIn, which compares them against everything posted on the internet, online article/paper databases, newspapers and magazines, and papers submitted by other students (including yourself if submitted for a previous class).

Note: Turning in an assignment (all or in part) that you completed for a previous class is considered self-plagiarism and falls under these guidelines. Any infractions of self-plagiarism are subject to the same penalties as copying someone else’s work without proper citations. Students who have taken this class previously and would like to use the work from previous assignments should contact the instructor for permission to do so.

 

Sexual Violence/Harassment:

Title IX is a federal law that provides that no person be excluded on the basis of sex from participation in, be denied benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity.  Both Title IX and university policy make clear that sexual violence and harassment based on sex is prohibited.  An individual who believes they have been subjected to sexual violence or harassed on the basis of sex can seek support, including counseling and academic support, from the university.  If you or someone you know has been harassed on the basis of sex or sexually assaulted, you can find information and resources at https://sexualviolenceprevention.asu.edu/faqs. 

As a mandated reporter, I am obligated to report any information I become aware of regarding alleged acts of sexual discrimination, including sexual violence and dating violence.  ASU Counseling Services, https://eoss.asu.edu/counseling is available if you wish to discuss any concerns confidentially and privately. ASU online students may access 360 Life Services, https://goto.asuonline.asu.edu/success/online-resources.html.

 

Prohibition of Commercial Note Taking Services:

All course content is copyrighted and any and all notes from in-person and/or online lectures may not be reproduced nor sold without explicit written permission from the instructor.  Students should consult the ACD 304-06 Commercial Note Taking Services  policy before written permission is sought from the official instructor of the class.  If permission to reproduce notes is granted, students may not use Blackboard email or discussion boards to advertise services to other students.  

 

Student Support and Disability Accommodations:

In compliance with the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, Section 504, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, professional disability specialists and support staff at the Disability Resource Center (DRC) facilitate a comprehensive range of academic support services and accommodations for qualified students with disabilities.

Qualified students with disabilities may be eligible to receive academic support services and accommodations. Eligibility is based on qualifying disability documentation and assessment of individual need. Students who believe they have a current and essential need for disability accommodations are responsible for requesting accommodations and providing qualifying documentation to the DRC. Every effort is made to provide reasonable accommodations for qualified students with disabilities.

 

Qualified students who wish to request an accommodation for a disability should contact their campus DRC at: http://www.asu.edu/studentaffairs/ed/drc/

If you are a student in need of special arrangements for we will do all we can to help, based on the recommendations of these services. For the sake of equity for all students, we cannot make any accommodations without formal guidance from these services.

 

Drop and Add Dates/Withdrawals:

Please refer to the academic calendar for the deadlines to drop/withdraw from this course as they tend to come up quickly (e.g. week 3 for 7 ½ week A/B session courses and week 11 for 15 week C session courses). Consult with your advisor and notify your instructor if you are going to drop/withdraw this course. If you are considering a withdrawal, review the following ASU policies: Withdrawal from Classes, Medical/Compassionate Withdrawal and Drop/Add and Withdraw.

 

Campus Resources:

As an ASU student you have access to many resources on campus. This includes tutoring, academic success coaching, counseling services, financial aid, disability resources, career and internship help and many opportunities to get involved in student clubs and organizations. 

  • Tutoring: http://studentsuccess.asu.edu/frontpage
  • Counseling Services: http://students.asu.edu/counseling
  • Financial Aid: http://students.asu.edu/financialaid
  • Student Accessibility and Inclusive Learning Services (formerly the Disability Resource Center: http://www.asu.edu/studentaffairs/ed/drc/
  • Major/Career Exploration: http://uc.asu.edu/majorexploration/assessment
  • Career Services: http://students.asu.edu/career
  • Student Organizations: http://www.asu.edu/studentaffairs/mu/clubs/

For more information about the School of Human Evolution and Social Change, including our degree programs, research opportunities and advising information, please go to: https://shesc.asu.edu/undergraduate-experience/undergraduate-advising. Our advisors are always willing to discuss career and guidance options with you. 

Help 

For technical support, use the Help icon in the black global navigation menu in your Canvas course or call the ASU Help Desk at +1-(855) 278-5080. Representatives are available to assist you 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

name: ASU 101-CAI: The ASU Experience (2023 Spring)
syllabus_body:
Faculty Information

Instructor: Michael C. Clough, Ph. D., mclough@asu.edu, office hours: M/W 10:00 am - 11:00 am in BYENG M1-10.

Section Leader: Tanay Jaiman, tjaiman@asu.edu

 

 

Student Expectations

  • Watch this video to learn how to use Canvas (Links to an external site.).
  • Start assignments early, and submit assignments on time!
  • Bring a device with internet access to every class meeting (laptop or smartphone)
  • This course uses GetSet, an external tool from Canvas that is automatically loaded when you complete the assignments. However, give yourself enough time in case of any issue happen, so you can submit your assignments within the proper time.

 

Course Information

Schedule

Day and Time: Tuesdays, 3:10 pm - 4:00 pm.

Location: BYENG 361

 

Course Description:

ASU 101 is a required, one-credit course designed to introduce all new first-time ASU students to the unique elements, culture, challenges, and opportunities of ASU and Fulton Schools of Engineering.

The course covers several core topics. Specifically, as a result of taking this class, you will be able to explain and define:

  1. How to be successful at ASU and in the STEM disciplines.
    • How to manage your time and resources
    • How to manage your academic content, including notetaking and reading skills
    • How to manage your relationships with peers from various backgrounds
    • How to thrive and be involved in your academic environment on your campus
  2. Academic integrity in your role as a scholar and student, and your connection to Fulton Schools of Engineering
  3. The professional path you have chosen, both during and after college, including learning experiences such as coops, internships, research, etc.

Credits: 1 (one)

Prerequisites: None

 

Textbooks

None

 

Grading

Course requirements

Your grade will be determined based on the following grading schema:

Grade Percentage
A+ 100% - 97%
A <97-90%
B <90-80%
C <80-70%
D <70-60%
E <60%

 

Course Schedule

A tentative course schedule is listed below: 

Week Date Topic
1 1/10/2023 Introduction, Syllabus, and Meet Classmates
2 1/17/2023 Resources and Connections
3 1/24/2023 Successful Student (Advising Visit)
4 1/31/2023 Succeed in Learning
5 2/7/2023 Library Tour (Section Leader)
6 2/14/2023 Academic Integrity and Ethics
7 2/21/2023 Successful Student (Advising Visit)
8 2/28/2023 Fulton Difference (Section Leader)
9 3/7/2023 No Class (Spring Break)
10 3/14/2023 Career Exploration
11 3/21/2023 Engineering Career Center
12 3/28/2023 Building your Financial Knowledge
13 4/4/2023 Inclusivity and Community
14 4/11/2023 No Class
15 4/18/2023 Conflict Management
16 4/25/2023 Semester Reflection

Communicating With the Instructor

ASU email is the official mean of communication among students, faculty, and staff. Students are expected to read and act upon emails in a timely fashion. Students bear the responsibility of missed messages and should check their ASU-assigned email regularly.

The Canvas site will be used to communicate due dates and course announcements. Students bear the responsibility of missed messages and should check their Canvas shell regularly.

All instructor correspondence will be sent to your ASU email account.

 

Course Policies

Electronic communication

All communication with ASU, including the instructors of this class, must come from your officially assigned asu.edu email address. If you use a different email you will need to have your asu.edu email forwarded to that address. The ASU Help Desk can assist you in accomplishing this.

 

Academic Integrity & Copyright Laws

One of the core topics of this course is academic integrity. You will be discussing it further throughout the course. ASU expects and requires all its students to act with honesty and integrity, and respect the rights of others in carrying out all academic assignments. Fulton Schools of Engineering takes academic integrity VERY seriously. The Fulton Honor Code will be discussed during a future class.

Students in this class must adhere to ASU’s academic integrity policy, which can be found at https://provost.asu.edu/academic-integrity/policy). Students are responsible for reviewing this policy and understanding each of the areas in which academic dishonesty can occur. In addition, all engineering students are expected to adhere to both the ASU Academic Integrity Honor Code and the Fulton Schools of Engineering Honor Code. All academic integrity violations will be reported to the Fulton Schools of Engineering Academic Integrity Office (AIO). The AIO maintains a record of all violations and has access to academic integrity violations committed in all other ASU colleges/schools.

 

Copyright

Course content, including lectures, are copyrighted materials and students may not share outside the class, upload to online websites not approved by the instructor, sell or distribute course content or notes taken during the conduct of the course (see ACD 304–06, “Commercial Note Taking Services” and ABOR Policy 5-308 F.14 for more information).

You must refrain from uploading to any course shell, discussion board, or website used by the course instructor or other course forum, material that is not the student's original work, unless the students first comply with all applicable copyright laws; faculty members reserve the right to delete materials on the grounds of suspected copyright infringement.

 

Threatening Behavior Policy

Students, faculty, staff, and other individuals do not have an unqualified right of access to university grounds, property, or services (see SSM 104-02). Interfering with the peaceful conduct of university-related business or activities or remaining on campus grounds after a request to leave may be considered a crime. All incidents and allegations of violent or threatening conduct by an ASU student ASU 101 Syllabus Fall 2020 page 2 (whether on- or off-campus) must be reported to the ASU Police Department (ASU PD) and the Office of the Dean of Students.

 

Harassment and Sexual Discrimination

Arizona State University is committed to providing an environment free of discrimination, harassment, or retaliation for the entire university community, including all students, faculty members, staff employees, and guests. ASU expressly prohibits discrimination, harassment, and retaliation by employees, students, contractors, or agents of the university based on any protected status: race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age, disability, veteran status, sexual orientation, gender identity, and genetic information. Title IX is a federal law that provides that no person be excluded on the basis of sex from participation in, be denied benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity. Both Title IX and university policy make clear that sexual violence and harassment based on sex is prohibited. An individual who believes they have been subjected to sexual violence or harassed on the basis of sex can seek support, including counseling and academic support, from the university. If you or someone you know has been harassed on the basis of sex or sexually assaulted, you can find information and resources at https://sexualviolenceprevention.asu.edu/faqs.

 

Disability Resources

Suitable accommodations will be made for students having disabilities. Students needing accommodations must register with the ASU disabilities resource Center and provide documentation of that registration to the instructor. Students should communicate the need for accommodation in sufficient time for it to be properly arranged.

name: ASU 101-CSE: The ASU Experience (2021 Fall)
syllabus_body:
Course Information (#73360)

Schedule

Day and Time: Monday, 4:40pm-5:40pm

Location: BYENG361

 

Faculty Information

Instructor: Dr. Robert Atkinson, robert.atkinson@asu.edu, office hours: TBA

Section Leader: Manav Shah, mashah5@asu.edu, office hours: Friday: 2:30 pm - 3:30 pm

Zoom link: https://asu.zoom.us/j/2207914701

Advisor: Michelle Shannon, Michelle.Shannon@asu.edu

 

Student Expectations

  • Watch this video to learn how to use Canvas (Links to an external site.).
  • Start assignments early, submit assignments on time!
  • Bring a device with internet access to every class meeting (Laptop or smartphone)
  • This course uses GetSet.  Read about how to use GetSet, and complete the prompts when assigned.

 

Course Description:

Course Policies

Attendance
Attendance and participation in class activities is an essential part of the learning process, and students are expected to attend class regularly. Some absences are, however, unavoidable. Excused absences for classes will be given without penalty to the grade in the case of (1) a university-sanctioned event [ACD 304-02]; (2) religious holidays [ACD 304-04; a list can be found here https://eoss.asu.edu/cora/holidays ]; (3) work performed in the line-of-duty according [SSM 201-18]; and (4) illness, quarantine or self-isolation related to illness as documented by a health professional.
 
Anticipated absences for university-sanctioned events, religious holidays, or line-of-duty activity should be communicated to the instructor by email at least 10 days before the expected absence.
 
Absences for illness, quarantine or self-isolation related to illness should be documented by a health professional and communicated to the instructor as soon as possible by email.
 
Excused absences do not relieve students from responsibility for any part of the course work required during the period of absence. Faculty will provide accommodations that may include participation in classes remotely, access to recordings of class activities, and make-up work.
  
In case you cannot attend class in person as a result of illness or possible exposure to infectious disease, you may participate in this class remotely via ASU Sync. Barrett Bridge Program
syllabus_body:
Barrett Bridge Program 

Welcome to the Barrett Bridge Program!

 The Bridge Program is for academically high-achieving and well-rounded first-year international students who are interested in applying to join Barrett, The Honors College, in spring 2022.    

There is an application to join Barrett (free to apply).  However, there is NO APPLICATION to join the Bridge Program. 

 

Students in the Bridge Program will receive:

  • invitations to a variety of Zoom events to get to know more about exclusive Barrett resources and opportunities
  • easy access to Barrett staff members in recruiting and admissions to ask questions about the honors application process
  • support towards spring enrollment in Barrett 
  • help connecting with other admitted students to ease the transition into the Barrett community in the spring

 

Barrett Application Process 

Application Deadline: Sunday, December 5, 2021
Student Notification: Wednesday, December 30, 2021

 

What is in the Application?

  • Two Letters of Recommendation (one has to be academic in nature) 
  • Unofficial transcript 
  • One 300-500 word essay 
  • Beyond the Classroom (information about extracurricular activities)
  • Optional Creative Supplement (100% optional)

name: COM 100: Intro to Human Communication (2022 Spring)
syllabus_body:
COM 100:  INTRODUCTION TO HUMAN COMMUNICATION

Spring 2022 –  (Class #10035)

Instructor:     Alexis Valianos, Ph.D.          Email: alexis.valianos@asu.edu

Virtual office appointments (through Zoom) are available Monday/Wednesday mornings (9am-10:30am) and other times by appointment.

Teaching Associates:

Kayla Yu                                    Email: panfengy@asu.edu

Office: Online office hours        Office hours: T/TH 10:30 am - 12 pm

*If you would like to meet with me during office hours, please email me and I will provide you with a zoom link.

Corey Reutlinger, Ph.D.           Email: creutlin@asu.edu

Office: Online office hours         Office hours: T/TH 12:00 noon - 1:30 pm

Welcome to Com 100! 

The course is designed to be both practical and academic. The material you’ll be reading and the information and examples I’ll by sharing are chosen because of their significance in the field of communication and their application for improving personal and professional interactions. You'll also be introduced to many of the HDSHC faculty and future communication classes you can take with them. 

My teaching philosophy is based on the goal of empowering students. As your instructor and your TAs, we are happy to answer your questions and we aim to be accessible to you via email (which is the best way to contact us) or our zoom virtual office hours. At the same time, to succeed, you should make use of the resources and teaching materials available in the syllabus and on Canvas. These materials provide answers to many questions, so please check them before reaching out. This demonstrates your commitment to the course and that you take your higher education and your role of “university student” seriously.

Please check your syllabus, as well as the schedule & REVEL calendars before emailing regarding course assignments and policies.

Let's get started!

If you have other questions about course content once you have checked the syllabus and REVEL Calendar, feel free to email us with your question. Please also email to schedule an appointment through zoom if you would like to take part in virtual office hours. Email the instructor or the teaching associates for questions regarding course subject matter, including lecture material and reading content.  All emails should be written in a professional manner by addressing the person appropriately, stating your question clearly, and signing off professionally. 

Please allow 1-2 business days for a response. Since instructors are teaching several classes and have other professional commitments each semester, please send an email or make an appointment if you’d like to meet with any instructor, even during office hours. Other students may already have scheduled or appointments with us during office hours.

Please NOTE:  As faculty, I have been directed by ASU to report all students who have tested positive to the Dean of Students for follow up. If you test positive or experience symptoms, please do not come to class, but do keep up with reading and assignments. All assignments can be turned in online (through canvas).

OBJECTIVES

Introduction to Human Communication provides an overview of key concepts and theories that guide our understanding of communication in various contexts (i.e., small group, mass media, computer mediated, etc.). Through lectures, discussion, and readings, this course will also survey topics related to the Hugh Downs School of Human Communication’s five specialty areas (i.e., interpersonal, organizational, intercultural, rhetoric, and performance studies). The primary goals of this course include developing your abilities to:

(1) define and describe the complex nature of communication,

(2) identify and describe the various contexts of communication study,

(3) recognize and explain the features of competent communication common to all contexts,

(4) connect theoretical concepts of communication to real-life experience, 

(5) define key terms used by communication researchers and practitioners, and

(6) begin to write and speak the language of the communication discipline.

REQUIRED MATERIALS AND TEXT 

  • Valid ASU email address and access to Canvas/MyASU/ASU Email
    • Set your Canvas notifications to alert you whenever an announcement  is sent out from the faculty. 
    • You must use your ASU email account, id, and login, if you want to email instructors,  attend Zoom office hours, and access digital text and course material 
  • Textbook (provided digitally through ASU’s Partnership program with Pearson publishing
    • Alberts, J. K., Nakayama, T. K., & Martin, J. N. (2021). Human Communication in Society, 6th ed. Upper Saddle River, Pearson Prentice Hall.
    • You are part of a class section that can access this material for free but you do need to register. Please read this Getting Started guide: https://pearsoncustomersuccess.co/ASUseamlessrevelstu for information on:
          • How to register into the course  
          • An FAQ section  
          • Resources and Support  
    • Contact Pearson’s 24/7 Technical Support
      • https://support.pearson.com/getsupport/s/ 
    • Check browser settings are set up for successful course access

NOTE: This course section uses a Pearson digital product which contains important assignments and resources used throughout the semester. Deadlines for Revel assignments cannot be extended or reopened under any circumstances. Your grades on the individual REVEL assignments can be viewed in the REVEL Scores page. Your final Revel grade on Canvas will be a calculation of your top 12 quiz scores.

Course Tutor: Mrs. Darien Keane,

Mrs. Keane can help students with research and study skills, review and understand course content, and remote learning support.

Tutoring hours:

COURSE REQUIREMENTS

You'll be expected to attend the in-person class lecture sessions on Mondays & Wednesdays so in an effort to protect your and others’ health, please read and follow the Covid-19 Protocols listed below: 

Covid-19 Protocols

Please read the following carefully and ask questions if you have any. These protocols apply in our class, subject to any procedural changes relating to Covid-19 promulgated by the University or my best judgment:

  • Wear a protective face covering that covers your nose and mouth during every class as per the current ASU policies for this semester: https://eoss.asu.edu/health/announcements/coronavirus#face-coverings
  • Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer before class.
  • Read the ASU Health Services FAQ page and follow all guidance and directives posted by the Provost’s Office. ASU Health Services Office of the Provost https://provost.asu.edu/sync/studentsLinks to an external site..
  • Don’t attend class if you have been diagnosed with Covid-19, live with someone who has Covid-19, or are at heightened risk of contracting Covid-19 per your doctor’s advice or ASU and CDC guidance (and common sense).

Graded and Ungraded work

Exams: There will be 3 exams total (Two regular exams, and One cumulative final). Each of the question on the exams are worth 2 points each.  One of these 3 exams will be dropped at the end of the semester.  Each exam will consist of around 45 questions (e.g., multiple-choice, true-false, and/or matching items). The exams will draw on material discussed in class and in the readings. The exam will be open for 24 hours. You will have 65 minutes to complete the exam once you start it. You will have only one chance to complete the exam. You should not navigate away because that will end your exam. We don't recommend using any online material while you are taking the exam. You will not have time to look up each answer so we do recommend that you study before you take the exam. You will not be required to use a lockdown browser for the first exam. Exams cannot be reset or reopened for any reason whatsoever. No late exams will be offered for any reason. You will take three exams this semester and we will keep the two highest scores.

Exam dates are provided under the daily schedule portion of the syllabus. Make a note of these dates as they are not flexible (so please plan accordingly). The regular exams will each cover select chapters from the textbook and all lessons taught in class. The cumulative final exam will cover material from all the chapters and all lessons taught in class. Individual exams are not returned. However, you are welcome to see our TAs during their office hours to go over questions about your exam.

You will have a set amount of time to take the exam on the exam day. You will not be allowed to take the exams in our classroom. You should not work with others on the exams.

Participation: There are are several days in this class where you'll be asked to complete participation exercises either in class or online. These can not be made up later or turned in late for points. 

Behavior such as lateness, leaving early, being disruptive or distracting, using electronic devices for any purpose besides taking notes for class, etc. can result in a reduced grade or deduction in your class points. You may or may not be spoken to or warned about the behavior. 

IMPORTANT NOTE:  AS RELATED TO THE ASU STUDENT ACADEMIC INTEGRITY POLICY: IN THIS CLASS, CHEATING, COLLUDING, HARASSING, DISRESPECTING, DISRUPTING, OR THREATENING BEHAVIOR IS NOT ACCEPTABLE AND YOUR GRADE MAY BE REDUCED AND/OR YOU MAY BE ASKED TO LEAVE THE CLASS. THE DEAN OF STUDENTS WILL BE NOTIFIED AND YOU MAY BE REMOVED FROM THE COURSE AND/OR RESULT IN SOME OTHER ACTION.

REVEL chapter quizzes There will be 14 assigned chapter quizzes in REVEL. You are expected to take each of these quizzes. Your score across the highest 12 chapter scores will be calculated to create your revel score. Past quizzes cannot be reopened for any reason.

Learning Activity: Students will be given time to complete specific, chapter-related activities. More information will be provided about this assignment.

POLICIES AND PROCEDURES

Attendance: You are expected to attend class and, importantly, to be on time and to stay for the entire class and be respectful and participate. You are responsible for any class material discussed in lecture, as well as the readings. Further, students who regularly attend class generally perform better than students who do not come to class. It is your responsibility to acquire missed material from classmates (i.e., the TAs can help you review material if you are absent due to illness). If you must come to class late or leave class early on a given day, please sit close to an aisle/door so you do not interrupt other students.

 Class presence and attention is linked directly with your success in the class. Your presence and attention in class will maximize your learning experience. Class time is intended to highlight the most important aspects from your reading, to further expand difficult concepts, and to provide an opportunity for questions.  In the event that you cannot attend class, arrange an appointment with a classmate to review the lecture. Once you have reviewed the missed material, any questions can be answered during office hours, by e-mail, or by appointment.

The instructor will deal with the following types of issues on a case by case basis: contagious or other illness or injury serious enough to require treatment by a doctor, death in the immediate family, religious holidays, and athletics or other university sanctioned events. Please note, however, that you will absolutely not be allowed to complete a late exam or assignment without full and official documentation. If you expect you might have a conflict that will prevent you from taking one or more exams on the scheduled day and time, you should consider taking another section of COM 100 or taking COM 100 during another semester when such conflicts will not exist.

A few additional/important things to note regarding late or missed exams/activities:

  • Make up exams may contain different questions and/or be in a different format than the original exam or quiz. For example, though regular exams will not contain essay questions, late exams may include essay questions.
  • Time is of the essence when late exams or assignments are approved. Therefore, all late exams and assignments must be completed A.S.A.P. (and no later than one week) after the original due date or you will receive a zero for a grade on that exam or assignment.\
  • Missed in-class activities and online quizzes (and the points from them) can not be made up for any reason. 

 Appealing a Grade:If you have any questions about your grade for a particular class assessment (including extra credit and clicker points, or penalties for inappropriate student conduct), you must submit them to me in writingwithin ONE WEEK(seven days) after the grade is originally returned/posted. In some instances (for reasons beyond my/your control), it may take more than a week to resolve an issue; but that will not be a problem as long as you originally raise the issue within one week. You are always welcome to go over questions after this deadline, but grades will not be adjusted after one week.

Readings and Participation: All readings should be done PRIOR to the assigned class period. Students are expected to participate fully and constructively in class discussions and activities.

 Student Conduct and Classroom Etiquette: This course is an mass lecture. Your enrollment in this course assumes that you will be an excellent listener and audience member for each lecture. You agree to treat your fellow classmates and instructor with respect; therefore, side conversations, watching videos, doing other class work, or disrupting or distracting in any way is not acceptable. Profanity or inappropriate comments concerning race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation and religion will not be tolerated. Any student who violates this policy will be asked to leave the classroom and/or may have their overall grade lowered in the course. Ways to avoid disrupting class include: coming to class on time, turning off all cell phones, not text messaging, not watching videos or listening to music, only using laptops and phones for note taking, not recording anything, not speaking when others are speaking, and not causing distractions for other students or doing other work during class. Thank you in advance for helping to create a positive learning environment.

We want to build a classroom climate that is professional and considerate for all. In a communication class, it is especially important that we (1) display respect for all members of the classroom – including the instructor and students, (2) pay attention to and participate in all class sessions and activities; (3) avoid unnecessary disruption during class time (e.g., having private conversations, reading the newspaper, surfing the internet, doing work for other classes, making/receiving cell phone calls, text messaging, etc.); and (4) avoid racist, sexist, homophobic or other negative language that may unnecessarily exclude members of our campus and classroom. This is not an exhaustive list of behaviors; rather, it represents examples of the types of things that can have a dramatic impact on the class environment. Engaging in such behaviors may result in the Dean of students being notified, class being observed, and/or students be permanently removed from the class. Examples of aggressive behavior include, but are not limited to, threats, cursing, raising your voice, throwing items, and using nonverbal behaviors (e.g., facial expressions, hand gestures, etc.) in ways that could be interpreted as aggressive or intimidating, or using communication technology to threaten or embarrass others. This is your only warning that such behaviors will not be tolerated.

Grade grubbing is the common term for complaining, begging, asking, demanding, or harassing the instructors and/or TAs to violate course policy. For example, requesting more points, to reopen missed assignments, etc. without legitimate cause. It is inappropriate and ineffective and very unprofessional and cannot be tolerated or overlooked. Any email requests for additional points, rounding up, extra work, more extra credit, or to reopen past assignments will not be responded to as we can not ethically provide you with special consideration or more points for any reason.  These requests or any inappropriate email or communication towards any instructor or TA will be forward to the Dean of Students and may result in additional disciplinary action.

Students are required to adhere to the behavior standards listed in the Arizona Board of Regents Policy Manual and the ACD 125: Computer, Internet, and Electronics Communications (http://asu.edu/aad/manuals/acd/acd125.html).

Students are entitled to receive instruction free from interference by other members of the class. An instructor may withdraw a student from a course when the student’s behavior disrupts the educational process under USI 201-10 (http://www.asu.edu/aad/manuals/policyarchives/USI/Mar2009/usi201-10.html). As noted in this document, “An instructor may withdraw a student from a course with a mark of “W” or “E” when the student’s behavior disrupts the educational process. Disruptive classroom behavior for this purpose is defined by the instructor.” In cases where disruptive behavior does not warrant removal from class, at the instructor’s discretion a student’s final grade will be lowered by 25% instead.

This class, as all others in the School, is taught in English. If English is not your first language and you are having difficulty in speaking, writing, or understanding—please seek assistance at the Writing Center on campus or with the International Student office which provides conversational groups for non-native speakers. Since this class is taught in English, all work in this course will be graded based on a common rubric that assumes an understanding of English.

While class is in session, students are encouraged to limit their personal electronics use. There are a number of reasons for this: first, it is substantiated by instructional research: Emailing, instant messaging, game playing, and web scrolling frequently distract students who use laptops and cell phones in the classroom. As a result, users provide less eye contact and participate less in class discussion. Second, technology use distracts other students in the class. Communication and technology experts Kinzer and Lohnes find that students are distracted by the sound of typing, the sight of screen glow, and other content, Finally, the use of this technology by students inhibits feelings of community in a classroom, because users are dually and only partially committed to two simultaneous contexts: the world of the classroom and online space. Students who would like to engage in better participation, get more out of course experience, and be recognized more by the instructors are encouraged to sit towards the front of the room and use hand written note taking.  There seems to be a correlation between people who pay better attention in class and sit towards the front and center and success in the class. 

Did you know that taking notes by handleads to better information retention? Psychologists at UCLA recently discovered that taking notes on laptops hinders academic performance. According to their study, students taking notes in longhand perform significantly better on exams than those who use laptops. Their findings were featured in the Journal of Psychological Sciences.

E-mail & Online Work: We will use electronic mail and the Canvas system (my.asu.edu or myasucourses.asu.edu) for class updates. Please check your e-mail and canvas accounts regularly (at least 2 times per week) so you can keep up to date. Please note that if you want to use an alternate email, you must redirect your ASU email address. Update your canvas notifications to alert you immediately of any announcements from class. 

No Photos, Videos, or Audio Recording:  Photos and video and audio recordings (i.e., of any course material, other students, the TA, or the instructor) may not be taken in this class without explicit written permission of the instructor. Students who violate this rule will have their grade lowered and/or be removed from the course. 

Dishonesty: In the Student Academic Integrity Policy, ASU defines plagiarism as “using another’s words, ideas, materials or work without properly acknowledging and documenting the source. Students are responsible for knowing the rules governing the use of another’s work or materials and for acknowledging and documenting the source appropriately.” You can find this definition, along with other important information and University policies regarding academic integrity, at: http://students.asu.edu/files/StudentCodeofConduct.pdf.

Academic dishonesty, including (but not limited to) plagiarism, inappropriate collaboration, copying the work/answers of another student (including test answers), possession of unauthorized notes/materials during  examinations (including, but not necessarily limited to, translators, cell phones, or other electronic devices) will not be tolerated. There are severe sanctions for academic dishonesty, including failure of the assignment, failure of the class, and expulsion from ASU.

Accommodation for Disabilities: Students with disabilities that have been certified by the ASU Disability Resource Center will be appropriately accommodated, should inform the instructor as soon as possible of their needs, and provide documentation no later than the second week of class. The Disability Resource Center is located at: Matthews Center, P.O. Box 873202, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287. Phone (480) 965-1234, TDD (480) 965-9000, Web Page http://www.asu.edu/studentaffairs/ed/drc/.

Disclaimer: The information provided in this syllabus (including the course requirements and tentative class schedule) constitutes a list of basic class policies. I reserve the right to modify this information when deemed necessary for any reason. You will be notified in class and/or via email/Canvas if/when any changes occur.

name: CSE 301: Computing Ethics (2023 Fall)
syllabus_body:
Syllabus

 

CSE 301: Computing Ethics

Fall 2023

Course Information

This is an ethics course for computing majors. The course begins with a brief review of the history of computing to illustrate the impact of technology on individuals and society.  Several ethical theories are introduced and then used to evaluate several topics in computing, including intellectual property, privacy, security, and computer reliability. With this knowledge, students are asked to reflect on their own professional ethical responsibilities in the course of their careers.

This course is taught as a iCourse or an online course.

Credits: 1

Prerequisites: CSE 205 or FSE 100 with C or better.

Notice:  All contents of this class, are under copyright protection. Notes based on these materials may not be sold or commercialized without the express permission of the instructor.  (Reference: ACD 304-06.)

Instructor Information

Instructor: Dianne Hansford, PhD
Contact Info: dianne.hansford@asu.edu  
 Office Hours: Monday 10:30 - 11:30 am and by appointment, held in my Zoom room
Office: BYENG M1-02  

Teaching Assistant: Vignesh Tirukkonda and Chenwei Cui
Contact Info: Please see the Discussion Forum before emailing. The class has been divided into two "Discussion Forum" groups, so please go to the Discussion Forum to find your TAs email.

Communicating with the instructor or TA:
This course uses the Discussion forum for general questions and comments about the course. Prior to posting a question or comment, check the syllabus, announcements, and existing posts to see if it has been addressed. You are encouraged to respond to the questions of your classmates.

Email questions of a personal nature to your instructor.  You must use your ASU email and put CSE 301 in the subject line. You can expect a response within 72 hours. ASU email is an official means of communication among between students, faculty, and staff. Students are expected to read and act upon emails in a timely fashion. Students bear the responsibility of missed messages and should check their ASU-assigned email regularly.

Emails regarding grading/assignments: Each student belongs to a "Discussion Group". (This is different from the "Discussion Forum" group.) You will find your group number upon opening a Discussion or Video assignment. Please communicate this number when emailing.

Course Learning Outcomes

At the completion of this course, students will be able to:

      1. Justify informed decisions in your career based on knowledge of IT history, IT legal structures, and widely accepted ethical theories.

      2. Evaluate new technology in a thoughtful manner, considering how it will impact individuals and society.

      3. Construct solid computing ethics arguments using practiced critical thinking skills.


This course satisfies the following Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology (ABET) Criterion 3 Outcomes:

      • An ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors.
      • An ability to communicate effectively with a range of audiences.
      • An ability to recognize ethical and professional responsibilities in engineering situations and make informed judgments, which must consider the impact of engineering solutions in global, economic, environmental, and societal contexts.

Textbook

Ethics for the Information Age (8th edition) by Michael J. Quinn, Pearson, 2020.
The textbook is required. The 8th edition is required.
See Module 1 for the Page "Accessing and Purchasing the Textbook" for information about gaining access to the textbook and purchasing it at a discounted price.

Course Organization

The course is organized into Modules. A link to the Modules page may be found in the Navigation section. One Module will be completed each week. Each Module consists of three sections:

      1. Introduction: Here you will find an introduction video and learning objectives.
      2. Learning Materials: Here you will find the required reading and possibly a video to watch.
      3. Learning Activities: Here you will find one or more assignments. Assessment types include
        • Quiz,
        • Discussion, and
        • Video/Discussion.

There are no exams.

      • Quizzes
        • You will take the quizzes in the Canvas Quiz tool.
        • Each quiz is composed of ten random questions from a pool of questions.
        • Questions are true/false, multiple choice, and fill-in the blank.
        • Quizzes are open book. Please do the work on your own.
        • Quizzes may be taken only once.
        • Quizzes have a maximum of 30 minutes to be completed from the time you start.  
        • The deadline time for all quizzes is 11:59 pm.
        • You must complete the quiz by the deadline to avoid a late penalty. (Keep in mind that Canvas can be slow or have problems near midnight.) See late penalty details in Evaluation and Grading Policies section below.
        • Answers to the quizzes are released upon submission.
        • Revealing the questions and/or answers to classmates before they have taken the quiz is an academic integrity violation.
        • Contact the Student Accessibility and Inclusive Learning Services (SAILS) if you need more time for the quizzes. SAILS will inform me as to your extra time allotment. This process takes time, so please begin the process within the first week of the semester.
           
      • Discussion Assignments
        • The Discussion forum is the Canvas Discussion tool.
        • You will post a reply to an assignment question and then respond to two peer responses.
        • Exact specifications for these assignments appear in the Assignment Guidelines Page.
        • Evaluation rubrics details are provided in the Assignment Guidelines Page.

      • Video/Discussion Assignments
        • You will be asked to create video presentations using Zoom.
        • You must appear in the video and you might be asked to include one or more slides to accompany your presentation.
        • The duration requirements of the video will be specified in the assignment. 
        • After you have submitted a video to the Discussion forum, the assignment will require you to post a comment on two peer posts.
        • Exact specifications for these assignments appear in the Assignment Guidelines Page.
        • Evaluation rubrics details are provided in the Assignment Guidelines Page.
        • In the Modules, the Video/Discussion assignments will be referred to as "Video", but there is always a Discussion forum aspect to them.
        • Please only submit one video. If you have made a mistake and need to resubmit, please be aware that only the last submission will be graded.

You will be assigned to a Discussion Group when Canvas opens. About 55 students are in each group. When you open the discussion-based assignments, you should see your group at the top of the page. When you submit your discussion-based assignments, you will be submitting to your group's area. You will interact with the other students in your group rather than the entire class. If for some reason, Canvas does not automatically assign you to a group, please reach out to one of the teaching assistants. (This can happen if you sign up for the class after Canvas has opened.) When emailing a question regarding an assignment, you must communicate your group number to the TA or instructor.

 

Evaluation and Grading Policies

Grades reflect your performance on assignments and adherence to deadlines.

Type How many? Percent of grade Each one counts
Quiz 14 20% 1.43%
Discussion 14 40% 2.87%
Video/Discussion 5 40% 8.0%

Grades on assignments will be available in the Gradebook. Quiz grades are available immediately after taking the quiz.

Late quizzes are penalized 5% per day. Quizzes may be submitted up until the last day of classes. The maximum late penalty is 50% of the assignment points. Please see the Absences and Make-up Policies section below for instances when a late penalty will not be applied.

Only with the appropriate documentation will late Discussion and Video assignments be allowed.

If you believe that your work was not graded correctly, then contact your TA immediately. (See the Discussion Forum for your TA.) We will not review grading more than one week after grades are posted. If your TA does not address your concerns, then you may contact the instructor.

At the end of the semester, do not ask for a grade boost or bump. Grades are only change based on merit.

Use of AI/Generative AI tools for graded work is not allowed, and use of these tools will be considered as academic dishonesty and a violation of the ASU academic integrity policy. This includes AI assisted grammar tools that significantly change your wording. If an AI detector flags your work, we will report the incident to the Dean's office.

Due Dates

In order to test your knowledge of a topic before you begin discussing it, the Quiz due dates are set before the Discussion and Video/Discussion assignment due dates.  

To help you balance your work load with other classes, all assignments open the first day of classes, so you may work ahead. However, you will not be able to complete your "reply to two peer posts" part of the assignments until others have posted. Also, this does allow you to complete your Discussion-type assignments before taking your Quiz, but I hope you follow the intended scaffolding of the assignments.

 

Grading Schema

Grade A+ A A- B+ B B- C+  C D E
Percentage >= 97 >= 94 >= 90 >=87 >= 84 >= 80 >= 77 >= 74 >= 60 < 60

Submitting Assignments

All assignments, unless otherwise announced, must be submitted to the designated area of Canvas. Do not submit an assignment via email.

Assignment due dates follow Arizona Standard time. Click the following link to access the Time Converter to ensure you account for the difference in Time Zones. Note: Arizona does not observe daylight savings time.

Late or Missed Assignments

For quizzes, the late penalty is 5% per day. (The deadline time is 11:59 pm.)

If you become sick or have a major life event that causes you to get behind in your work, please contact the instructor. Late work may be made-up if a valid excuse and documentation is presented at the time of the event.

Follow the appropriate University policies to request an accommodation for religious practices or to accommodate a missed assignment due to University-sanctioned activities .

Course Access

Your ASU courses can be accessed by both my.asu.edu and https://asu.instructure.com; bookmark both in the event that one site is down.

Honors Contracts

Honors contracts are not offered for this course.

Computer Requirements

This is a fully online course; therefore, it requires a computer with internet access and the following technologies:

    • Web browsers (Chrome,  Mozilla Firefox, or Safari)
    • Adobe Acrobat Reader (free)
    • Adobe Flash Player (free)
    • Webcam, microphone, headset/earbuds, and speaker
    • Microsoft Office (Microsoft 365 is free for all currently-enrolled ASU students)
    • Reliable broadband internet connection (DSL or cable) to stream videos.

Note: A smartphone, iPad, Chromebook, etc. will not be sufficient for completing your work in ASU Online courses. While you will be able to access course content with mobile devices, you must use a computer for all assignments, quizzes, and virtual labs.

Student Success

Academic Integrity

View the ASU Online Course Policies 

Students in this class must adhere to ASU’s academic integrity policy, which can be found at https://provost.asu.edu/academic-integrity/policy). Students are responsible for reviewing this policy and understanding each of the areas in which academic dishonesty can occur. In addition, all engineering students are expected to adhere to both the ASU Academic Integrity Honor Code and the Fulton Schools of Engineering Honor Code. All academic integrity violations will be reported to the Fulton Schools of Engineering Academic Integrity Office (AIO).  The AIO maintains record of all violations and has access to academic integrity violations committed in all other ASU college/schools.

Violations of the University's Academic Integrity policy will not be ignored. Violations will be reported to the Dean's office. Penalties include reduced or no credit for submitted work, a failing grade in the class, a note on your official transcript that shows you were punished for cheating, suspension, expulsion, and revocation of already awarded degrees.

Please review the university academic integrity policy webpage.

Also review Student's Rights and Responsibilities, Code of Conduct, and policies to create a safe learning environment.

Copyright

Course content, including lectures, are copyrighted materials and students may not share outside the class, upload to online websites not approved by the instructor, sell or distribute course content or notes taken during the conduct of the course (see ACD 304–06, “Commercial Note Taking Services” and ABOR Policy 5-308 F.14 for more information).

To print: MAC users press "⌘" + "P". PC users press "CTRL" + "P".

CSE 310: Data Structures and Algorithms

Course and Faculty Information

Course Description: Advanced data structures and algorithms, including stacks, queues, trees, and graphs. Searching for graphs, hashing, sorting

Credits: 3

Prerequisites:  Comp Systems Engineering BSE, Comp Science BS, Informatics BS, Engineering Mgmt BSE or Computational Math Sci BS; CSE 220 or 240 with C or better; MAT 243 with C or better (CMS students may substitute MAT 300) or CSE Graduate student

Instructor: Dr. Janaka Balasooriya

Contact Info: Email: janakab@asu.edu

Office : 578, Brickyard

 Office Hours :                     Monday 3.00 - 4.00 pm (In-person 578 Brickyard)

                                              Thursday 10 am - 11.00 am (In-person 578 Brickyard)

                                              Wednesday 6.00  - 7.00 pm (Online)

                                             https://asu.zoom.us/j/86236479241

 

Graduate TA:

Please reach out to Utkarsh if you have any recitation-related questions:

Name/email: Utkarsh Nath , unath@asu.edu

Office hours:  Mon and Wed 12 - 1 pm

Zoom Link: https://asu.zoom.us/j/2762615237

 

Undergraduate TAs (Please note that undergraduate TAs do not participate in grading, please do not contact them related to grading questions) :

 

Name/email: Nathaniel Ezra Lee Zheng, nlee51@asu.edu

Office hours:  Friday 12pm - 1:30 pm and 2pm - 3:30pm

Zoom Link:  https://asu.zoom.us/j/83395616469

 

Name/email: Neelay Singhvi, nsinghvi@asu.edu

Office hours: Monday and Wednesday, 6:30 pm - 8:00 pm

Zoom Link: https://asu.zoom.us/j/8691193305

 

Name/email: Adi Keshava Reddy Mamilla, amamill1@asu.edu

Office hours: Monday - 1pm-2:30pm, Tuesday- 3pm-4:30pm

Zoom Link: https://asu.zoom.us/j/83686617957

 

NOTE: 

Also, the contents of this course, including lectures and other instructional materials, are copyrighted materials.  Students may not share outside the class, including uploading, selling or distributing course content or notes taken during the conduct of the course.  

Course Learning Outcomes 

At the completion of this course, students will be able to:

    1. Students who complete this course can define data structures (types) such as heaps, balanced trees, hash tables.
    2. explain how to use a specific data structure in modeling a given problem (e.g. I can explain how to model a dictionary using balanced trees).
    3. identify, construct, and clearly define a data structure that is useful for modeling a given problem.
    4. state some fundamental algorithms such as merge sort, topological sort, Prim's and Kruskal's algorithm, and algorithmic techniques such as dynamic programming and greedy algorithms.
    5. use a specific algorithmic technique in solving a given problem (e.g. I can write a dynamic program that solves a shortest-path problem).
    6. design an algorithm to solve a given problem.
    7. define the notions of worst-case/best-case/average-case running times of algorithms.
    8. analyze and compare different asymptotic running times of algorithms.
    9. analyze a given algorithm and determine its asymptotic running time.
    10. combine fundamental data structures and algorithmic techniques in building a complete algorithmic solution to a given problem.
    11. create several algorithmic solutions to a given problem and choose the best one among them according to given requirements on time and space complexity.

Major Topics Covered

  • Asymptotic Notation
  • Worst-case Analysis
  • Sorting, Lower Bound for Sorting, Heaps, and Heap sort
  • Median, Selection Problems: More on Divide-and-Conquer Algorithms
  • Hashing
  • Binary Search Trees, Red-Black Trees
  • Disjoint Sets (union-find): Introduction to Amortized Analysis
  • Longest Common Subsequence: Introduction to Dynamic Programming
  • Graph Algorithms (Depth-First Search, Breadth-First Search, Topological Sort, MST: Greedy
  • Algorithms, Shortest Paths

Class Format/Attendance
