Academic Integrity:

Students in this class must adhere to ASU’s academic integrity policy, which can be found at https://provost.asu.edu/academic-integrity/policy). Students are responsible for reviewing this policy and understanding each of the areas in which academic dishonesty can occur. In addition, all engineering students are expected to adhere to both the ASU Academic Integrity Honor Code and the Fulton Schools of Engineering Honor Code. All academic integrity violations will be reported to the Fulton Schools of Engineering Academic Integrity Office (AIO).  The AIO maintains record of all violations and has access to academic integrity violations committed in all other ASU college/schools.

Unless explicitly allowed by your instructor, the use of generative AI tools on any course assignment or exam will be considered academic dishonesty and a violation of the ASU Academic Integrity Policy. Students confirmed to be engaging in non-allowable use of generative AI will be sanctioned according to the academic integrity policy and FSE sanctioning guidelines.

Specific academic integrity rules for this class are The Student Academic Integrity Policy of Arizona State University requires each student to act with honesty and integrity and to respect the rights of others in carrying out all academic assignments. There are a number of actions that constitute a violation of the policy.  These actions include, but are not limited to:

    •  practicing any form of academic deceit;
    •  referring to materials or sources or employing devices (e.g., audio recorders, crib sheets, calculators, solution manuals, or commercial research services) not specifically authorized by the instructor for use during tests, quizzes, homework, and class activities;
    • acting as a substitute for another person in any academic evaluation or using a substitute in any academic evaluation;
    • possessing, buying, selling, or otherwise obtaining or using, without appropriate authorization, a copy of any materials intended to be used for academic evaluation in advance of its administration;
    •  depending on the aid of others to the extent that the work is not representative of the student’s abilities, knowing or having good reason to believe that this aid is not authorized by the instructor;
    • providing inappropriate aid to another person, knowing or having good reason to believe the aid is not authorized by the instructor;
    • submitting the ideas or work of another person or persons without customary and proper acknowledgment of sources (i.e., engaging in plagiarism);
    •  permitting one's own ideas or work to be submitted by another person without the instructor’s authorization; or attempting to influence or change any academic evaluation or record for reasons having no relevance to class achievement.
    •   turning in work/code done by someone else
    • copying work/code done by someone else
    • writing one code together with someone else (it should be individual work)

We have no problem failing you in this class for the semester and having the appropriate entries placed in your ASU student records. All instances of cheating will be handled by the Dean's office according to the ASU Student Academic Integrity Policy and the USI 104-01: Student Code of Conduct and Student Disciplinary Procedures.

Copyright

Course content, including lectures, are copyrighted materials and students may not share outside the class, upload to online websites not approved by the instructor, sell, or distribute course content or notes taken during the conduct of the course (see ACD 304–06, “Commercial Note Taking Services” and ABOR Policy 5-308 F.14 for more information).

You must refrain from uploading to any course shell, discussion board, or website used by the course instructor or other course forum, material that is not the student's original work, unless the students first comply with all applicable copyright laws; faculty members reserve the right to delete materials on the grounds of suspected copyright infringement.

Students, faculty, staff, and other individuals do not have an unqualified right of access to university grounds, property, or services. Interfering with the peaceful conduct of university-related business or activities or remaining on campus grounds after a request to leave may be considered a crime. All incidents and allegations of violent or threatening conduct by an ASU student (whether on- or off-campus) must be reported to the ASU Police Department (ASU PD) and the Office of the Dean of Students. 

Disability Accommodations

Suitable accommodations are made for students having disabilities. Students needing accommodations must register with the ASU Student Accessibility and Inclusive Learning Services office and provide documentation of that registration to the instructor. Students should communicate the need for an accommodation in enough time for it to be properly arranged. See ACD 304-08 Classroom and Testing Accommodations for Students with Disabilities.

Harassment and Sexual Discrimination

Title IX is a federal law that provides that no person be excluded on the basis of sex from participation in, be denied benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity.  Both Title IX and university policy make clear that sexual violence and harassment based on sex is prohibited.  An individual who believes they have been subjected to sexual violence or harassed on the basis of sex can seek support, including counseling and academic support, from the university.  If you or someone you know has been harassed on the basis of sex or sexually assaulted, you can find information and resources at https://sexualviolenceprevention.asu.edu/faqs. 

 

As a mandated reporter, I am obligated to report any information I become aware of regarding alleged acts of sexual discrimination, including sexual violence and dating violence.  ASU Counseling Services, https://eoss.asu.edu/counseling is available if you wish to discuss any concerns confidentially and privately. ASU online students may access 360 Life Services, https://goto.asuonline.asu.edu/success/online-resources.html.

name: CSE 360: Intro to Software Engineering (2023 Fall)
syllabus_body:
1.     Contact Information

This course is an overview of software engineering. It will cover the following topics:

Instructor:       Lynn Robert Carter, Ph.D.

Office:               BYENG 524

Email:  LynnRobertCarter@asu.edu

2.     Office hours

Tempe:  To Be announced and by appointment.

Poly:       2 p.m. to 4 p.m. on the following dates:

                     Aug 28, Sep 11, Sep 20, Oct 2, Oct 16, Oct 25, Nov 06, Nov 15, Nov 27.

3.     Course Description

This course is a survey of software engineering with a focus on the following:

  • Software lifecycle models
  • Software development methods and tools (Eclipse, Astah, Java, JavaFX, JUnit, and Git)
  • Unified Modeling Language (UML)
  • Software project management
  • Software testing
  • Software quality assurance
  • Introduction to Information management (SQL, SQLFiddle)

Credits and Course Method

This course is a three-credit-hybrid course. Students attend a single 75-minute in-class interactive session each week. The core lectures and supporting material have been captured and are available online.  This includes various readings, links to online readings, and other materials.  The in-class sessions are not optional and the results of these in-class activities must be uploaded to course Canvas in order to earn class-participation credit.

During the scheduled in-class meetings, key concepts are reviewed, activities are performed, questions are answered, and team learning activities are performed. The in-class meetings are required, the in-class sessions are not recorded, the slides used in-class do not cover everything from the in-class activities, and the material covered in the in-class sessions will be included in the Major Quizzes, the Midterm Exam, and the Final Exam. If you are unable to make an in-class session, ask your teammates to take notes and help you understand what happened.

4.     Prerequisites or co-requisites

CSE 220 or CSE 240 with C or better OR Computer Science or Software Engineering graduate student OR Visiting University Student; Biomedical Informatics BS or Computer Science BS or Digital Culture (Media Processing) Ba/BS or Geographic Information Science BS or Computer Systems BSE or Engineering Management BSE major.

If you don't meet the official prerequisites but are admitted into the course because you did courses "equivalent" to the official prerequisite courses, it is your responsibility to make sure you understand the necessary background material and can use your understanding in the course activities, assignments, quizzes, and examinations.

5.     Outcomes and Objectives

1. Students will develop an understanding of software engineering topics, including:

  • Understand basic software engineering approaches for producing requirements, designs, code, tests, and maintenance changes, and perform basic quality assurance.
  • Develop an awareness of national and international standards.
  • Develop an initial awareness of the local and global impacts of their solutions.

2. Students understand and learn to follow a disciplined software development process and will be able to:

  • Identify the set of involved key stakeholders.
  • Gain an understanding of stakeholder requirements elicitation and documentation.
  • Enhance and update a vision for a solution to the stakeholders’ needs and capture it as a concept of operation document.
  • Given a Concept of Operations document, produce a set of the received requirements.
  • Given a Concept of Operations document and a set of the received requirements, produce and document the derived requirements.
  • Given the stakeholder needs and a Concept of Operations document, explain how the software architecture satisfies and is in alignment with them.
  • Produce basic detailed designs that are in alignment with the above-listed deliverables using UML.
  • Learn and practice using standard software development tools (E.g., Java, JavaFX, GitHub, UML, Astah,
  • Prototype solutions in Java and JavaFX using Eclipse to reduce implementation risks resulting in updates, if needed, to the above-listed deliverables and the prototypes so they remain in alignment.
  • Integrate the prototypes, required library routines (e.g., using APIs), required subsystems (e.g., databases), and other code as required to produce a tested, working, and well-documented prototype of the entire application.
  • Explore how to reason about program correctness and describe how it was achieved.
  • Follow a code of ethics concerning the use of the work of others (including AI tools such as, but not limited to, ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot).

3. To work effectively on a software development team, the student will:

  • Plan and track a software development effort.
  • Use an agile process with regular scrums to ensure effective communication.
  • Conduct software reviews and inspections.
  • Present software products and process results in oral and written form.

6.     Topics

This course is an overview of software engineering. It will cover the following topics:

  • Software lifecycle models
  • Software development methods and tools
  • Unified Modeling Language (UML)
  • Software project management and configuration management using GitHub
  • Software implementation and testing using an agile approach
  • Software quality assurance
  • Introduction to Information Management

7.     Textbook and Recommended Reference Materials

  • Required Textbook: Software Engineering, 10th Edition, Ian Sommerville, Pearson, 2016
    ISBN-13: 978-0-13-394303-0

This textbook is automatically made available to you in a digital form inside the course Canvas.  You will be charged for this digital book.  You may choose to opt out (see details below).

The required material for this course, Software Engineering, will be provisioned as an e-book and made available at a discounted price significantly cheaper than if purchased directly from the publisher.  If you wish to take advantage of this discounted group price, no additional action is needed.  Following the drop/add period, a charge of $39.00, plus tax, will post to your student account under the header “Digital Integrated Course Mtrl” and your access will continue uninterrupted.   

If you'd rather purchase the material from an alternate source, you may choose to opt out of the program by using this link:   https://includedcp.follett.com/1230† Enter your ASU e-mail address AS IT APPEARS IN THE ASU DIRECTORY (http://asu.edu/directory), then follow the instructions provided.  Be aware that if you do opt out, your access to the e-book will be discontinued.

TO ACCESS THE E-BOOK, CLICK ON THE BRYTEWAVE TOOL IN YOUR COURSE’S CANVAS SHELL.  Please note: the ebook won’t appear on your shelf until approximately 5 days before the start of classes. If you need assistance accessing the book or the opt-out portal, fill out the support request form: https://forms.gle/uD4GhBxMoixnbwYx5 

†Link is campus specific: 

Tempe/Online: https://includedcp.follett.com/1230 

Poly: https://includedcp.follett.com/1232 

West: https://includedcp.follett.com/1233 

Downtown: https://includedcp.follett.com/1234 

  • Unified Modeling Language Standards, http://www.uml.org/

8.     Required Course Tools

Web browsers (Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, or Safari)

PDF Reader (Adobe Acrobat Reader – free version)

Computer Equipment  (Webcam, microphone, headset/earbuds, and speaker)

Productivity Tools (Microsoft Office – Microsoft 365 is free for all currently-enrolled-ASU students)

Internet (Reliable broadband internet connection (DSL or cable) to stream videos.)

Programming Language for Projects/Individual Assignments:

  • Java (Required) Please use the most current version that runs on your machine/OS.
  • JavaFX (Required) Please use the most current version that runs on your machine/OS.
  • Eclipse  (Required) Please use the most current version that runs on your machine/OS.

Project Management (Not required, but highly recommended):

  • Jira (free version)
  • Microsoft Project

UML Modeling:

  • Astah (Required, UML diagrams drawn using any other tool or hand-drawn UML diagrams will not be accepted). Astah has a free version for students

Unit Testing:

  • JUnit (Required)

Project Repository:

  • GitHub (Required)

9.     Barrett Honors Enrichment Contracts

This course supports students wishing to earn honors credit from the Barrett Honors College. To learn more about this program click here.

Students wishing to earn honors credit must propose a project that extends some practical aspect of the Team Project being done by the student’s team. Even though it extends the team’s project, the extension must be done individually without input from or impact on the rest of the student’s team.

There are three options for a CSE 360 Honors Enrichment Contract. The first two add or expand project requirements (functional or non-functional) so that they align with the Customer Need documentation but are considered out-of-scope for the work the team will perform. Successful contracts require the submission of the same project documentation required of the team, but with change bars on the side of the text, figures, and other items indicating the enhancements performed. In addition, a screencast must be produced and submitted using PowerPoint slides to explain the need and value of the project followed by a demonstration of the enhancement. This screencast must be appropriate to show your capabilities to a potential employer.

Option 1: Identity an enhancement to the course project beyond what the team has agreed to produce that would align with and bring value to some aspect of an ASU sustainability initiative.  Explore this website for ideas: https://schoolofsustainability.asu.edu.

Option 2: Identify a weakness from the MITRE Common Weakness Enumeration Top 25 for 2023 and enhance all the project deliverables to address that weakness.  Please ensure your PowerPoint slides and presentation explains the weakness and how it was removed from the project.  Explore the MITRE CWE Website: https://cwe.mitre.org/top25/.

Option 3: Leverage aspects of the team project to create a new smaller application that aligns with and brings value to some aspect of an ASU sustainability initiative.  Explore this website for ideas: https://schoolofsustainability.asu.edu.

If you are interested in this opportunity, please schedule an appointment with your professor.  Performing a Barrett Honors Contract for CSE 360 requires regular check-ins and status updates with the professor (at least once every other week).

10.  Course Timeline

11.  Use your ASU Email

ASU email is an official means of communication among students, faculty, and staff. Students are expected to read and act upon email messages in a timely fashion. Students bear the responsibility of missed messages and should check their ASU-assigned email regularly.

  • Always use your ASU email address to contact your Instructor, TAs, and Staff Members.
  • Use the subject line and always start it with the course number as a prefix followed by the topic of the message. Doing this will improve your chances to receive a prompt reply.
  • Try to resolve issues with the TAs first. The only exception is when the issue is confidential. In that case, start with your professor.

12.  Evaluation and Grading Policies

Your course grade will be based on the distribution below:

  • Exams 40% [Midterm (15%) and Final (25%)]
  • Quizzes 20% [10 Minor Quizzes (0.2% each) and 2 Major Quizzes (9% each)]
  • Team Project 25% [2000 points must be earned to be awarded the entire 25%]
    • 5 Project Assignments (260 points each – 1300 points total – 65% of the 25%)
    • Final Project Assignment (400 points – 400 points total – 20% of the 25%)
    • 6 Peer Reviews (50 points each – 300 points total – 15% of the 25%)
  • Assignments 10% [5 Individual Assignments (2% each for a total of 10%)]
  • Participation 5% [In-class Activity Submissions]

The following is the grading scale that will be used in the course:

 

  • A+ >= 97% and <= 100%
  • A >= 94% and < 97%
  • A- >= 90% and < 94%
  • B+ >= 87% and < 90%
  • B >= 84% and < 87%
  • B- >= 80% and < 84%
  • C+ >= 76% and < 80%
  • C >= 70% and < 76%
  • D >= 60% and < 70%
  • E < 60%

Excused absences for classes will be given without penalty to the grade in the case of (1) a university-sanctioned event [ACD 304-02]; (2) religious holidays [ACD 304-04]; a list of religious holidays can be found here https://eoss.asu.edu/cora/holidays]; (3) work performed in the line-of-duty according to [SSM 201-18]. Students who request excused absences must follow the policy/procedure guidelines. Excused absences do not relieve students of responsibility for any part of the coursework required during the period of absence.

Grades will not be curved and will not be rounded up.  Requesting curving or rounding up of grades is unethical.  Grades reflect your performance on assignments and adherence to deadlines. Grades on assignments will be available within two weeks of the due date in the Gradebook.

Any discrepancy or disagreement in grading must be presented within one week of receiving your graded materials; otherwise, no grade change will be made.

The best way to “improve” your grade is to be proactive.  Rather than asking for extra work to make up for a poor grade on an assignment, be proactive, start early, identify things that you do not know well, ask questions on the Canvas Slack, and ask questions in class.

The grade of "I" (incomplete) can ONLY be given when a student, who is otherwise doing good work (i.e., a passing grade), is unable to complete a part of work (e.g., the final exam) because of documented illness or other ASU-recognized extenuating circumstances beyond the student's control.  In the latter case, the student must discuss with the instructor and complete an application form from the department before the work is due or as soon as the circumstances are known. Please see ASU grading policies at: https://students.asu.edu/grades.

Exams

  • Two exams (a midterm and a final exam) will be given during the semester.
  • Both exams will be comprehensive. Exams may consist of multiple-choice, fill-in-the-blank, short answer, programming problems, or any combination thereof. Exams are drawn from a bank of questions and your exam is not likely to be the same as others in the class.
  • The Midterm will be virtual: The final will be online and require you to use the Respondus LockDown Browser + Webcam. You are urged to take this at school in a Library or some other quiet place where ASU is providing Internet Access.
  • Final will be held in the classroom: The final will be online and require you to use the Respondus LockDown Browser + Webcam. Special arrangements must be made in advance if you need to take this examination at some location other than the classroom. There are no exceptions to this requirement.

Assignments and Quizzes

  • Assignments and quizzes will be given throughout the semester. They are designed to help you practice the concepts you need to learn in this class. Finding the answer somewhere is not the same as practice. Programming and other projects should take you anywhere from thirty minutes to ten hours to complete, depending on your skill level and study habits. They may include a written portion, a programming portion, or both. If you have trouble, please take advantage of office hours and other helpful resources, such as the Canvas Slack tool and tutoring services. Assignments (including Quizzes and exams) and projects can never be made up and can never be turned in late. The only exceptions are those mentioned in ASU policies (e.g., medical) and ASU-recognized extenuating circumstances.
  • Minor and Major Quizzes: There are 10 Minor Quizzes taken on Wednesdays and 2 Major Quizzes taken on Fridays. Quizzes are online and are available for an entire day.

Minor Quizzes are worth 0.2% of the course grade each for a total of 2% of the course grade.  These quizzes are taken from materials found in the textbook and other assigned readings.  You may use a browser of your choice, but you are urged to use an ASU Library or other ASU facility that is quiet and provides ASU-supported internet connections.  You are allowed three attempts. Perform these quizzes early in the day so it is possible to recover from a computer problem, an internet problem, or some other issue.

Major Quizzes are worth 9% of the course grade each for a total of 18% of the course grade.  These quizzes are cumulative and include materials from the minor quizzes, the recorded lectures, and the in-class activities. These quizzes are online, require you to use the Respondus LockDown Browser + Webcam, and you are urged to use an ASU Library or other ASU facility that is quiet and provides ASU-supported internet connections. If you have a problem with your internet connection or your computer, contact your professor immediately via a text message at (480) 334-1429. You will have to make special arrangements later to retake the quiz and only the unanswered questions from your initial attempt will be allowed from the second attempt.

  • Team Project: In teams of 5 members, students will produce multiple project deliverables including documents and programs. In unusual situations, your team may be asked to accept an additional team member, but your team will not be forced to accept this new member. Project deliverables will be discussed in class. All team members are expected to participate in the creation of all deliverables. The grade for the team project may be decreased if there is inadequate participation and no effort was made to address it. Each team member is responsible for helping the other members be successful. Deliverables and due dates will be announced and discussed in the lecture. No late submissions will be accepted for the class project. In addition, a report due at the end of the team project will include an evaluation of your team’s work, your contributions as well as those of your teammates. Specific templates for each project submission for the deliverable content will be provided, the instructions in the template must be followed, and the template must be used to create the submission.
  • Individual Assignments: Students will produce five (5) individual assignments with a focus on tools, coding, and testing. Please take advantage of the office hours of the TAs, Graders, UGTAs, and the professor, and other provided resources, such as the discussion board and ASU tutoring services if you need additional help.
  • Submission requirements: All assignments and other submissions must be made using a file name that starts with your ASURITE ID, followed by an underscore, followed by either the word Assignment or Project, followed by an underscore, followed by a digit that specifies which assignment or project submission. Furthermore, every assignment and project submission must have your name prominently located on the first page of the submission. Failure to follow these requirements will result in an immediate deduction of 10% of the total points for the submission.
  • In-Class Activities and Participation: Unless an accommodation has been established for medical or other ASU-recognized extenuating circumstances, all students are expected to come to the class and participate. If you have an ongoing medical condition, please contact ASU SAIL at https://eoss.asu.edu/accessibility to obtain an accommodation.
  • All submissions are checked for plagiarism and improper AI usage.
  • All assignments, unless otherwise announced, must be submitted as specified in the assignment to the designated area of Canvas with URLs to GitHub or Google Drive for code, videos, and other large files. Do not submit an assignment via email.
  • Assignment due dates and times are based on Arizona Standard Time. Click here to access a Time Converter to ensure you properly account for any difference in Time Zones. (Do not use Arizona – Navajo Nation time)
    Note: Arizona does not observe daylight savings time.
  • Due times: Do not wait until the last minute to upload an assignment or finish a quiz or exam. Many technical issues can influence upload speeds (e.g., Internet issues, Wi-Fi issues, and computer issues). If the upload is not complete before the deadline, it will not be accepted.  Behave like a responsible professional and complete your work early, so you have options in case you are confronted with a technical issue.
  • Notify the instructor before an assignment or project submission, quiz, or exam is due if an urgent situation arises (or in the case of an unforeseen emergency, as soon as possible) making it impossible to submit the assignment on time.
  • Follow University policies to request religious accommodations. Accommodations can be made for religious observances if a student properly notifies the instructor at the beginning of the semester concerning those dates. To request religious accommodations please complete ASU’s Religious Accommodation Request Form. Once you submit the completed form to Accessibility@asu.eduASU will review it and follow up with you regarding the next steps.
  • Students who expect to miss class due to officially university-sanctioned activities should inform the instructor early in the semester. Alternative arrangements will generally be made for any examinations and other graded in-class work affected by such absences. This policy is ACD 304–02, "Missed Classes Due to University-Sanctioned Activities."

Getting Help

Be proactive.  Identify risks. Do the risky and hard parts first so you have time to try another way if your initial ideas do not work.  If you have questions, use the Slack tool available from Canvas.  Your professor, TAs, and Graders (as well as your classmates) may be able to respond much more quickly than the time to schedule an appointment and wait for office hours or an email response.

Try to get your questions answered via Slack first, as you are much more likely to get a quick response that way.  If that does not work, email your question to the TAs. As a last resort, come to the professor’s office hours or schedule an appointment.  (Be mindful of the number of students each professor supports and it may take a day or two for a response to an email.)

Do not expect your Professors, TAs, or Graders to be available to help you during weekends or outside of normal business hours. Schedule your coursework with this reality in mind. They may make themselves available to support the class, but that should be viewed by you as these individuals making a special effort to help you.

13.  Policy Regarding Expected Student Behavior

Students in this class are expected to acknowledge and embrace the FSE student professionalism expectation located at: https://engineering.asu.edu/professionalism/.

Cell phones and pagers must be muted during class to avoid causing distractions. The use of recording devices is not permitted during class.

How Long Students Should Wait for an Absent Instructor? In the event the instructor fails to indicate a time obligation, the time obligation will be 15 minutes for class sessions lasting 90 minutes or less, and 30 minutes for class sessions lasting more than 90 minutes. Students may be directed to wait longer by someone from the academic unit if they know the instructor will arrive shortly.

14.  Academic Integrity, Honor Code, and AI Tools

Students in this class must adhere to ASU’s academic integrity policy, which can be found at https://provost.asu.edu/academic-integrity/policy. Students are responsible for reviewing this policy and understanding each of the areas in which academic dishonesty can occur. All engineering students are expected to adhere to the ASU Academic Integrity Honor Code.

 

 

All work submitted for the course cannot have been submitted for any other course or any previous section of this same course. Student academic integrity violations are reported to the Fulton Schools of Engineering Academic Integrity Office (AIO). Withdrawing from this course will not absolve you of responsibility for an academic integrity violation and any sanctions that are applied. The AIO maintains a record of all violations and has access to academic integrity violations committed in all other ASU colleges/schools.

Unless explicitly allowed by your instructor, the use of generative AI tools on any course assignment or exam will be considered academic dishonesty and a violation of the ASU Academic Integrity Policy. Students confirmed to be engaging in the non-allowable use of generative AI will be sanctioned according to the academic integrity policy and FSE sanctioning guidelines.

You are encouraged to cooperate in study groups as you learn the course materials. However, you may not cooperate with others as you prepare individual assignments. Anything you turn in for those assignments must be your work (i.e., you must write up your own solution based on your understanding). If you use an idea that is found in a book or from other sources, or that was developed by someone else or jointly with some group, make sure you acknowledge the source and/or the names of the persons (i.e., formal source citation) in the write-up for each problem. When you help your peers, you should never show your work to them.

All assignment questions must be asked using Canvas Slack. Asking assignment questions or making your assignment available on public websites before assignments are due will be considered a violation. All individual tests must be done independently. Working together during tests is not permitted.

The instructor and the TA will carefully check any possible proliferation or plagiarism by comparing it with other student submissions, previous student submissions, and publications on public Web sites. We will use the document/program comparison tools to check all assignments and tests that you submitted for grading.

 

All cases of cheating or plagiarism will be handed to the Dean's office. Penalties include a failing grade on an assignment, a failing grade for the class, suspension, expulsion, and revocation of already awarded degrees, and a note on your official transcript may be added that shows you were punished for cheating or plagiarism.

 

Fulton Schools of Engineering Honor Code   https://engineering.asu.edu/integrity/

Given the profound impact of engineering on public health, safety, and welfare, I recognize the great importance of ethics to the engineering profession. I further recognize that integrity and ethical behavior as an engineer are directly linked to academic integrity and ethical behavior as an engineering student. In recognition of this statement, all students should strive to adhere to each of these principles:

  1. Seek out, acquaint myself with, and obey the instructor’s rules concerning the materials I am allowed to use and the types of collaboration in which I am permitted to engage in each of my courses.
  2. Help my fellow engineering students to succeed both academically and professionally, while both following the instructor’s guidelines on collaboration and encouraging my classmates to behave ethically.
  3. Ensure that all of my individual work products reflect my own abilities and not those of someone else. I will never copy the work of others or give others the opportunity to copy mine.
  4. Contribute a fair share of work to all teamwork in which I participate and acknowledge the contributions of others. I will accept responsibility for the integrity of all work submitted by my team.
  5. Use only aids authorized by the instructor during all examinations, quizzes, projects, assignments, and other evaluations.
  6. Provide aid to or receive aid from other students only as permitted by the instructor.
  7. Give full credit to others for their words and ideas, whether directly quoted or paraphrased, using proper citation practices in all of my work, including text, figures and computer code, and all materials obtained from the Internet.
  8. Never act dishonestly including lying, cheating, stealing, or attempting to corrupt the academic enterprise in any way.
  9. Ensure that all data I record or report is objective, true, accurate, and properly documented.
  10. Treat all students, faculty, and staff with respect, courtesy, and dignity, the way I would like to be treated myself.
  11. Recognize that it is how I act when no one else is watching that defines my true character.
  12. Act at all times with integrity, as the true professional that I am to become.

AI Tools (including ChaptGPT and GitHub Copilot): When the use of AI tools is explicitly authorized in writing in an assignment, their use without proper citation is deemed to be in violation of Academic Integrity.  According to Association for Computing Machinery (ACM).  “The use of generative AI tools and technologies to create content is permitted but must be fully disclosed in the Work. For example, the authors could include the following statement in the Acknowledgements section of the Work: ChatGPT was utilized to generate sections of this Work, including text, tables, graphs, code, data, citations, etc.). If you are uncertain ¬about the need to disclose the use of a particular tool, err on the side of caution, and include a disclosure in the acknowledgments section of the Work.”  This requirement is for all individual and team deliverables, including documentation and code.

15.  Student Copyright Responsibilities

You must refrain from uploading to any course shell, discussion board (including Slack), or website used by the course instructor or other course forum, material that is not the student's original work, unless the students first comply with all applicable copyright laws; faculty members reserve the right to delete materials on the grounds of suspected copyright infringement.

The contents of this course, including lectures and other instructional materials, are copyrighted materials. Students may not share outside the class, including uploading, selling, or distributing course content or notes taken during the conduct of the course. Any recording of class sessions is authorized only for the use of students enrolled in this course during their enrollment. Recordings and excerpts of recordings may not be distributed to others. (see ACD 304–06, “Commercial Note Taking Services” and ABOR Policy 5-308 F.14 for more information).

16.  Policy against threatening behavior, per the Student Services Manual, SSM 104–02

Students, faculty, staff, and other individuals do not have an unqualified right of access to university grounds, property, or services (see SSM 104-02). Interfering with the peaceful conduct of university-related business or activities or remaining on campus grounds after a request to leave may be considered a crime. All incidents and allegations of violent or threatening conduct by an ASU student (whether on- or off-campus) must be reported to the ASU Police Department (ASU PD) and the Office of the Dean of Students.

 

17.  Disability Accommodations

Students with disabilities who require accommodations should complete a registration form.  (Click here.) Once this form is submitted, students will receive an automatic confirmation email. Within a few days of submission, students will be contacted, through their ASU e-mail by their assigned Accessibility Consultant (DAC) with information to set up their initial appointment. This appointment is essential to establishing eligibility and beginning the interactive process to determine accommodations. If there are questions at any point before being connected with your DAC, you can contact them at (480) 965-1234 or send an email to student.accessibility@asu.edu.  See ACD 304-08 Classroom and Testing Accommodations for Students with Disabilities.

 

18.  Harassment and Sexual Discrimination

Arizona State University is committed to providing an environment free of discrimination, harassment, or retaliation for the entire university community, including all students, faculty members, staff employees, and guests. ASU expressly prohibits discrimination, harassment, and retaliation by employees, students, contractors, or agents of the university based on any protected status: race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age, disability, veteran status, sexual orientation, gender identity, and genetic information.

Title IX is a federal law that provides that no person be excluded on the basis of sex from participation in, be denied benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity. Both Title IX and university policy make clear that sexual violence and harassment based on sex are prohibited. An individual who believes they have been subjected to sexual violence or harassed on the basis of sex can seek support, including counseling and academic support, from the university. If you or someone you know has been harassed on the basis of sex or sexually assaulted, you can find information and resources at https://sexualviolenceprevention.asu.edu/faqs.

As a mandated reporter, your professors are obligated to report any information they become aware of regarding alleged acts of sexual discrimination, including sexual violence and dating violence. ASU Counseling Services, https://eoss.asu.edu/counseling is available if you wish to discuss any concerns confidentially and privately. ASU Online students may access 360 Life Service,       
 https://goto.asuonline.asu.edu/success/online-resources.html.

19.  Syllabus Disclaimer

Syllabus changes: Any information in this syllabus (other than grading and absence policies) may be subject to change with reasonable advance notice.

In-writing specifications for any class activity, assignment, quiz, or exam may require the use of specific tools, programming languages, and so forth. Written assignment specifications override any general or generic statements made in this syllabus.

Grade Calculation: (This total score will be out of 113, and will not be capped. )

Total score = (Weekly RA %)*5 + (Quiz %)*5 + (Assignment %)*50 + (Exams %)*40 + (Extra assignments %)*11 + (extra quizzes %)*2
The individual percentages should be calculated as:
1) weekly RA % = (total score in 10 RAs) *100/1000
2) quiz % = (total score in 1st 10 quizzes) *100/100
3) assignment % = (total score in highest 10 assignments out of assignments 1-10, extra assignments 1-2 and in-class exercises) *100/500
4) exams % = (midterm + endterm scores) *100/200
5) extra assignments % = (total score in 6 bonus questions) *100/110
6) extra quizzes % = (total score in 4 extra quizzes) *100/40

name: ENG 107: First-Year Composition (2021 Fall)
syllabus_body:
Hello my students,

This is ENG 107 First Year Composition (Fall 2020) class, meeting at BA 390 (TTH 4:30-5:45 pm). 

Please download the course syllabus by clicking here and carefully read that. 

Your new instructor:

Instructor Contact Information

  • Instructor Name: Dragana Graovac
  • Office Location: Online via Zoom: https://asu.zoom.us/j/3201389158
  • Office Hours: T/Th from 10:00-2:00 (by appointment) Please email me to schedule the time.
  • Email: dgraovac@asu.edu

Response Policy

I will respond to emails and Canvas messages within 48 hours (if not sooner).  My office phone is not the best way to contact me, so please use email.  I will grade all assignments within one to two weeks of the date of submission.

Credentials/Instructor Bio

My name is Dragana Graovac and I have been privileged and happy to teach at Scottsdale Community College and Arizona State University. I got my BA in English from Arizona State University and my MA in English from Saint Louis University, where I started my teaching career. Because Saint Louis University has a satellite campus in Madrid, Spain, I was lucky to study there for 2 years and teach and live in Madrid for almost 3 years. Aside from teaching English and helping students succeed, I have a passion for world literature, film, and photography. I love to travel, learn about different cultures, habits, foods and languages, and when home in Phoenix, I enjoy spending time with my family, hiking around Flagstaff and Sedona, and binging on Netflix.

I am looking forward to learning more about you as the semester progresses.

Course Description

EPICS Gold is a service-learning course in which EPICS teams are formed from students potentially representing all engineering, computer science and construction disciplines, as well as other ASU majors, including sustainability, business, liberal arts, sciences and others. Groups of 4+ students in this class will work together to develop design solutions for representatives of community partners.  The students are expected to make significant progress on a project and have a prototype by the end of the semester to solve the partner’s problems. Projects are intended to solve real problems, are defined in partnership with their community partners, and span the complete design process cycle [problem identification to problem service/ maintenance – sustainability – retirement]. The EPICS projects in this course often take 3+ semesters to be completed. Interdisciplinary group interaction is an integral element for the project success. Student participation for multiple consecutive semesters on a project is encouraged. Groups are composed of students of any year in their undergraduate studies at ASU.

Credit Amount:

FSE 104 : 1 credit

FSE 404: 1 or 2 credits. Pick the credit amount when you add the course. If you are already in FSE404, you need to drop and re-add the course. When you re-add it, after clicking add from the class search, the next screen shows the credit amount. Click the credit amount, it is a drop down menu, and change to 2 credits.

FSE 404: 1 credit is only the 50 minute team meeting. The 2 credit FSE404 is the 50 minute team meeting plus 10 hours of skill sessions. Skill sessions include in-person events, guest speakers, industry mentor skill sessions, additional prototyping time outside of class, being a team leader and completing the respective documentation, and select online videos such as approved coursera, linkedin learning, udemy, recorded in-person skill sessions, guest speakers, etc. All video recording skill sessions require additional verification for credit.

Prerequisite: None

Textbook: None- Digital Readings are provided on course Canvas site.

Students are expected to access the course website on a regular basis for announcements, readings, and assignment submission. As a 1-credit C-session course, students are expected to participate for 3-4 hours every week for the full semester.

*All students (104/404) are required to join an EPICS team and attend their team's weekly team meeting, which takes place during one of the 404 sections (times are listed above).

**104 students are also required to attend a lecture at their 104 class registered time slot.

 

Course Schedule

There are four types of teams in EPICS 1) Stage 0 teams which are brand new teams without a community partner. Stage 0 teams will be Stage 1 teams within 2-3 weeks, 2) Stage 1 teams which are brand new teams with a community partner, 3) Stage 2 teams which are planning or actively working on their first prototype, and 4) Stage 3 teams which are teams that are on their 2nd+ iteration of their functional prototype. Grading:

In EPICS, students work on teams; final individual grades will reflect both the quality and quantity of the student’s documented individual accomplishments and learning and skill development, as well as the group’s accomplishments. All team members are responsible for the progress and ultimate success of the project. Teams will work together to identify project goals for the semester. Individual roles and responsibilities within the team and projects will be identified and documented throughout the semester.

 

Attendance – 25 points

  • 1 free absence per 104 & 404 class
  • Each absence over 1 results in a 2.5 point (2.5% of final grade) deduction
  • 5* Absences will result in a 10 point or 10% reduction or going from an A to a B
    • *This assumes no other points are deducted in the course
  • Please review the attendance policy for sick students

Progress - 30 points

  • Syllabus Quiz (1pt)
  • Scope and Effort (5pts)
  • Team Norms & Team Summary document (1pt)
  • Budget Submission/Testing Plan (1pt)
  • Team Progress Tracking (1pt)
  • Final Transition Video (1pt)
  • Mentor Evaluation of Progress (10pts)
  • End of Semester Progress Report (10pts)

Design Review Presentation – 20 points

Design Document – 15 points

CATME Peer Evaluations - 10 points (5pts for Midterm and 5pts for Final)

*Skills Sessions (1 point per hour completed)

**Extra credit will be at the discretion of the faculty instructor. 

**To earn an A+ students must complete 5 additional hours of skills sessions AND receive a grade above a 97.5 before extra credit.

Grade Components:

Design Reviews/Presentations (20%)

Design Reviews are formal opportunities to present team progress on their projects. This semester there will only be 1 main design review which will take place on week 11. For new projects, design reviews will be 10 minutes followed by 10 minutes of questions, returning projects will be more in-depth presentations (i.e. 20-minutes) followed by 20 minutes of questions and discussion. Design reviews are technically focused detailing the project and community partner background, illustration of project design, technical design elements (drawings, schematics, test results, prototypes, and models), and material covering broader contextual material including ethical implications. These are usually held during the evenings of the team meetings to allow participation of industry mentors and external parties. Students must attend and actively participate in their design review to receive credit for this portion of the class.

Stage 3 teams may elect to have a 1 hour in-depth industry design review for a more comprehensive review of their project.

 

Attendance (25%)

On time attendance at all classes including team meetings is required, and attendance will be taken. 104 students will be evaluated on their cumulative class and team attendance. 404 students will be evaluated on just their team attendance. It is better to show up late than not at all. Nevertheless, if time-sensitive exercises have begun lateness could entail disqualification from graded activities. One absence per semester may be excused by the class instructor if the class missed doesn’t involve any type of team presentation or otherwise require the attendance of all team members. Assignments are to be submitted prior to or on the due date electronically or as directed by the instructor. Late assignments will result in a 50% point reduction.

Attendance is required for all class sessions. Excessive tardiness (more than 5 minutes late to a lab) may cause a reduction in the participation grade.  Missing a lab will result in a grade deduction.  An absence will not be counted against a student for:

  1. excused absences related to religious observances/practices that are in accord with ACD 304–04, “Accommodation for Religious Practices”
  2. excused absences related to university-sanctioned events/activities that are in accord with ACD 304–02, “Missed Classes Due to University-Sanctioned Activities”
  3. excused absences related to missed class due to military line-of-duty activities that are in accord with ACD 304–11, “Missed Class Due to Military Line-of-Duty Activities,” and SSM 201–18, “Accommodating Active Duty Military”

Anticipated absences for university-sanctioned events, religious holidays, or line-of-duty activity should be communicated to the instructor via e-mail at least 48 hours before the expected absence.

Absences for illness, quarantine, or self-isolation related to illness should be documented by a health professional and communicated to the instructor as soon as possible.  Excused absences do not relieve students from responsibility for any part of the course work required during the period of absence. Faculty will provide accommodations that may include participation in classes remotely, access to recordings of class activities, and make-up work.

In case you cannot attend class in person as a result of illness or possible exposure to infectious disease, you will be able to participate in this class remotely via ASU Sync.  You must email the UGTA for the course to obtain an excused absence (if accepted). To participate remotely join via the zoom link provided at the top of the syllabus.  Note that all students should bring a mobile device to class regularly to allow participation with colleagues via ASU Sync as necessary. ASU-sync is only offered to students who have been excused from class by the instructor.

 

CATME Evals & Self Reflection (20%)

EPICS team members will assess the group’s ability to function as a high performing team, communicate effectively, and contribute to the community partner’s desired outcomes. These assessments will be sent via your official ASU email from CATME as a link to the survey and will be completed twice each semester at the design reviews. Students will receive credit for their completion of the assessments of their group members, as well as receive credit based on the numeric scores assigned to them by the other group members.

Self reflection assignment is due at the end of the semester and details the students progress in the course as it relates to a variety of skill areas (technical, soft, and career aspirations).

 

Progress (30%)

Progress will be evaluated by the team semester project plan and the final progress report assignment. Teams should aim to meet both faculty and community partner expectations. Since all EPICS projects are unique, there is no objective rubric for this score.  Your industry mentor will meet with your team weekly and report your progress based on the goals you set the prior week and course progression through the design process. Throughout the semester, the team, EPICS faculty, and the community partner will have chances to provide feedback on expectations and progress will be measured against those expectations. The grade is based on Scope and Effort (5pts), Team Norms (1pt), Team Summary document (1pt), Budget Submission/Testing Plan (1pt), Team Progress Tracking (1pt), Final Transition Video (1pt), Mentor Evaluation of Progress (10pts), and End of Semester Progress Report (10pts).

 

Assignments (optional)

There are weekly team-based assignments which can be used to guide and document your progress throughout the phases of the design process this course covers. These assignments are especially practical for new teams in creating their first design document draft. Suggested due dates are included in the course schedule.

 

Design Document (15%)

The design document is a compilation of the team’s progress through the human-centered design process, and is mostly compiled by synthesizing the weekly assignments into a single coherent document. It is a professionally written report that covers all activities engaged in by the team over the semester. It should contain at a minimum: project description, biographical information about the team members, sections on each completed phase of the EPICS design and development process, figures/graphs/photos/etc. illustrating the models, data analysis, prototyping, and other work accomplished and project impact. In general, this can be completed by merging the weekly assignments, incorporating any feedback from the grading process semester and design reviews throughout the semester, and additional work that hadn’t been included. A grading rubric will be available for reference for the assessment of the design document, and students will have the chance to get feedback throughout the semester in a non-graded checkpoint (see course schedule for due date).

 

Skill Sessions (1% extra credit per hour)

Skill sessions are opportunities for students to advance their knowledge as it relates to their EPICS project and/or their future academic career. Students must document their participation at each skill session via a form accessible via Canvas within 48 hours of the completion of the skill session. Skill sessions may be eligible for extra credit and will be determined by the instructional team.

All skill sessions must be submitted with the follow template: Skill Session Report Template Document

 

Grade Appeals and Incompletes

ASU has formal and informal channels to appeal a grade. If you wish to appeal any grading decisions, please see  http://catalog.asu.edu/appeal (Links to an external site.). A mark of "I" (incomplete) is given by the instructor when you have completed most of the course and are otherwise doing acceptable work but are unable to complete the course because of illness or other conditions beyond your control. You are required to arrange with the instructor for the completion of the course requirements. The arrangement must be recorded with: http://students.asu.edu/forms/incomplete-grade-request (Links to an external site.).

Course Outcomes:

Discipline Knowledge: ability to apply material from their discipline to the design of community-based projects.

Design Process: an understanding of design as a start-to-finish with a strong emphasis on sustainability and maintenance as they’re delivering the products to real clients.

Lifelong Learning: ability to identify and acquire new knowledge as a part of the problem solving/ design process.

Client Awareness: ability to identify client needs and work to develop solutions that effectively address those concerns. 

Teamwork: an ability to function on multidisciplinary teams and an appreciation for the contributions from individuals from multiple disciplines.  Unlike other classes, EPICS students will be joining projects in various states of completion introducing a different team dynamic than typical courses.

Communication: an ability to communicate effectively with others from varying backgrounds. This includes communicating clearly in writing, as a speaker, and while using interpersonal communication skills.

Broader Context: an appreciation of the role that their discipline can play in political, environmental, and social contexts.

Ethics: Developing and delivering projects for real clients will require students to continue to advance the importance of professional ethics and responsibility

Entrepreneurial Mindset: Curiosity: demonstrating constant curiosity about the changing world and exploring a contrarian view of accepted solutions. Connections: integrating information from many sources to gain insight and assessing and managing risk. Creating Value: identifying unexpected opportunities to create extraordinary value and persisting/learning from failure.

 

Email Communications

All email communication for this class will be done through your ASU email account, especially when communicating with your community partner or with the faculty, staff, TAs, or AAs. If you send mail from a third-party email address (e.g. a gmail.com email address), the instructional staff is not allowed to respond as we cannot verify your identity. You are solely responsible for reading and responding if necessary to any information communicated via email or Canvas.

Typical Industry Requirements for Email Responses

  • Format
    • Must include class, day, and time
    • Example: FSE104, Monday at 10:30am
  • Response time
    • 24-48 business hours on average (Limited responses on weekends)
    • Late Friday/Weekend emails will be responded to no later than Tuesday
  • If you do not obtain a response
    • Send follow up email after 3 business days
    • Talk to instructor before, after, or during class (as appropriate)
  • Availability outside of class
    • Nightly team meetings (404 class times)
    • Office hours
    • By appointment
  • Easiest way to get info
    • Ask before, during, or after FSE104 class or nightly team meetings
  • Questions that require back and forth correspondence should be completed before/during/after class or during office hours

 

Student Standards and Classroom Behavior

Students are required to read and act in accordance with university and Arizona Board of Regents policies, including the ABOR Code of Conduct: Arizona Board of Regents Policies 5-301 through 5-308: https://students.asu.edu/srr (Links to an external site.) . Students are entitled to receive instruction free from interference by other members of the class. If a student is disruptive, an instructor may ask the student to stop the disruptive behavior and warn the student that such disruptive behavior can result in withdrawal from the course. An instructor may withdraw a student from a course when the student's behavior disrupts the educational process under USI 201-10 (http://www.asu.edu/aad/manuals/usi/usi201-10.html (Links to an external site.)). Course discussion messages should remain focused on the assigned discussion topics. Students must maintain a cordial atmosphere and use tact in expressing differences of opinion. Students should follow proper ‘netiquette’ throughout the entire online course.

Cell phones and pagers should be turned off during class to avoid causing distractions unless used for official coursework.  The use of recording devices is not permitted during class.  Any violent or threatening conduct by an ASU student in this class will be reported to the ASU Police Department and the Office of the Dean of Students. 

 

Academic Integrity

ASU expects and requires all its students to act with honesty and integrity, and respect the rights of others in carrying out all academic assignments. Each student in this class is expected to abide by the ASU Academic Integrity Policy and Student Code of Conduct. Discussions are encouraged for assignments. However, individual assignments must be your own work. Copying is not allowed. Academic dishonesty includes borrowing ideas without proper citation, copying others’ work (including information posted on the internet), and failing to turn in your own work for group projects. Teamwork must be the original work of the team and each team member is expected to participate in the teamwork. Any infractions of self-plagiarism are subject to the same penalties as copying someone else’s work without proper citations.

Team assignments are expected to be completed by ALL members of the team, although the details of how each member participates will be left up to the individuals in the team with respect to team roles. It is up to the team to document who worked on each assignment and their main contributions. Zero credit will be given to individuals who fail to contribute in team assignments. If a team is found to be awarding credit to a team member who has not been contributing to an assignment, all team members will be reported for Academic Dishonesty and are reported to the Dean of Engineering.

You are encouraged to work with others on assignments. However, assignments denoted as individual assignments MUST be your own, original work. If you work with others on these assignments, you must acknowledge their help. Direct copying of others’ assignments will result in an XE for this course. Cheating on exams will also result in an XE for this course. For more information, see http://provost.asu.edu/academicintegrity (Links to an external site.). All violations will be reported to the Dean’s office, who maintain records of all offenses.  Students are expected to abide by the FSE Honor Code (http://engineering.asu.edu/integrity/ (Links to an external site.)).

 

Prohibition of Commercial Note Taking Services

In accordance with ACD 304-06 Commercial Note Taking Services (Links to an external site.), written permission must be secured from the official instructor of the class in order to sell the instructor's oral communication, lectures, or classroom materials in the form of notes.  Notes must have the note taker’s name as well as the instructor's name, the course number, and the date.

 

Student Support and Disability Accommodations

Qualified students with disabilities may be eligible to receive academic support services and accommodations (Links to an external site.). Eligibility is based on qualifying disability documentation and assessment of individual need. Students who believe they have a current and essential need for disability accommodations are responsible for requesting accommodations and providing qualifying documentation (Links to an external site.) to the DRC. Every effort is made to provide reasonable accommodations for qualified students with disabilities. Qualified students who wish to request an accommodation for a disability should contact their campus DRC at: http://www.asu.edu/studentaffairs/ed/drc/ (Links to an external site.)

 

Drop and Add Dates/Withdrawals

Please refer to the academic calendar (Links to an external site.) on the deadlines to drop/withdraw from this course.  Consult with your advisor and notify your instructor if you are going to drop/withdraw this course. If you are considering a withdrawal, review the following ASU policies: Withdrawal from Classes (Links to an external site.), Medical/Compassionate Withdrawal (Links to an external site.). 

 

Campus Resources

As an ASU student you have access to many resources on campus. This includes tutoring, academic success coaching, counseling services, financial aid, disability resources, career and internship help and many opportunities to get involved in student clubs and organizations. 

Tutoring: http://studentsuccess.asu.edu/frontpage (Links to an external site.)

Counseling Services: http://students.asu.edu/counseling (Links to an external site.)

Financial Aid: http://students.asu.edu/financialaid (Links to an external site.)

Student Accessibility Center: https://eoss.asu.edu/accessibility 

Major/Career Exploration: http://uc.asu.edu/majorexploration/assessment (Links to an external site.)

Career Services: http://students.asu.edu/career (Links to an external site.)

Student Organizations: http://www.asu.edu/studentaffairs/mu/clubs/ (Links to an external site.)

 

Sexual Discrimination and Harassment

Title IX is a federal law that provides that no person be excluded on the basis of sex from participation in, be denied benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity.  Both Title IX and university policy make clear that sexual violence and harassment based on sex is prohibited.  An individual who believes they have been subjected to sexual violence or harassed on the basis of sex can seek support, including counseling and academic support, from the university.  If you or someone you know has been harassed on the basis of sex or sexually assaulted, you can find information and resources at https://sexualviolenceprevention.asu.edu/faqs (Links to an external site.). 

As a mandated reporter, I am obligated to report any information I become aware of regarding alleged acts of sexual discrimination, including sexual violence and dating violence.  ASU Counseling Services, https://eoss.asu.edu/counseling (Links to an external site.), is available if you wish discuss any concerns confidentially and privately.

ASU policy prohibits harassment on the basis of race, sex, gender identity, age, religion, national origin, disability, sexual orientation, Vietnam era veteran status, and other protected veteran status. Violations of this policy may result in disciplinary action, including termination of employees or expulsion of students. Contact Student Life (UCB 221) if you feel another student is harassing you based on any of the factors above; contact EO/AA (480-965-5057) if you feel an ASU employee is harassing you based on any of the factors above.

 

Syllabus Disclaimer:

The course syllabus is an educational contract between the instructor and students. The instructor reserves the right to make changes to the syllabus as deemed necessary. Students will be notified of any syllabus changes in the Canvas Announcements section.

name: GLG 101 Online: 13187-13188 (2023 Spring - A)
syllabus_body:
GLG 101 Online: Introduction to Geology I

To print: MAC users press "⌘" + "P". PC users press "CTRL" + "P".

Credits: 3

Prerequisites: None

Instructor: Julia Johnson 

Communicating With the Teaching Assistant or Instructor

Email

ASU email is an official means of communication among students, faculty, and staff. Students are expected to read and act upon email in a timely fashion. Students bear the responsibility of missed messages and should check their ASU-assigned email regularly.

All instructor correspondence will be sent to your ASU email account.

Primary email contact: geology.asu@gmail.com Use this for everyday questions about assignments, grades, course content, and issues with Canvas. For other major issues, such as health emergencies, email the faculty instructor. (julia.johnson@asu.edu)

Office Hours: We do not meet face-to-face with online students.

Course Description

The Earth is diverse and dynamic, featuring volcanoes, earthquakes, tsunamis, landslides, floods, and so on. As citizens, we want to understand what is going on in our natural world and which aspects directly affect us or are most interesting. Understanding past events help us comprehend what has happened and begin to predict future events. With the Earth, we examine past events and current natural processes to understand how this past and these processes affect humans. Accordingly, this course examines the processes and materials composing Earth’s physical environment, for example, its landscapes and interior. We will explore topics such as natural hazards and disasters, fossils, energy resources, and much more. To do so, we will learn some underlying principles of the natural world, from small things like the very building blocks of matter (atoms), to large things, like the cause and effect of regional forces that build mountains (e.g., the Himalaya) and make new oceans (e.g., the Red Sea). These processes are active today on Earth and give rise to earthquakes, volcanoes, and landslides, all of which obviously affect humans. You are required to complete all assignments in a timely manner as detailed in the Assignment Schedule at the end of this syllabus.

Course Learning Outcomes

At the completion of this course, students will be able to:

  1. Be able to observe and interpret landscapes, maps, and other expressions of geology in our world 
  2. Be able to solve basic geologic problems, such as reconstructing the sequence of events in a landscape
  3. Be able to summarize and explain the most important concepts in physical geology
  4. Be able to identify and explain the relevance of geology to society
  5. Be able to explain how geoscientists approach geologic problems

Textbook and Connect

The textbook for this course is Exploring Geology, by Reynolds, Johnson, Morin, and Carter, 6th Edition. We will be using this textbook in conjunction with Connect, the publisher’s learning tools. Your registration into this course gives you instant access to the textbook as a “SmartBook” (essentially an interactive ebook) as well as the bulk of the assignments you need for this course (your ASU account will be charged ~$80 after the official drop/add period passes). The first time you access Connect, you will be asked to set up a username and password that you will use for the entire session. You may opt out from this, but if you do, you'll be charged more to register. You may purchase ($25) a loose-leaf version of the textbook via the publisher (free shipping) or by going to the ASU Bookstore-Tempe Campus. The loose-leaf version of the textbook is optional.

This is a unique textbook designed to help you learn geologic concepts and processes on your own. Nearly all the information in the book is built around illustrations and photographs, rather than being in long blocks of text. The entire book consists of a series of two-page spreads organized into chapters. Each two-page spread is a self-contained block of information about a specific topic and has a short list indicating what you should be able to do before you leave these pages. The items from these lists, for which you will be held responsible for knowing, are compiled into a What-To-Know List that is downloadable from this course’s Canvas website. The What-To-Know List is your guide to what is important, and all assignments are derived from this list. If, when studying from the book, you construct your own answer to each item on the What-To-Know List, then I predict you will receive an A in the class. Required reading is listed in each chapter’s What-To-Know List. Each two-page spread in the book has a unique number (e.g., 12.4), and these numbers are referenced for quizzes and other course assignments. Each chapter ends with an investigation concerning a problem associated with a “virtual place”.

Course Access

Your ASU courses can be accessed by both my.asu.edu and myasucourses.asu.edu; bookmark both in case one site is down.

Computer Requirements

This is a fully online course; therefore, it requires a computer with internet access and the following technologies:

  • Web browsers (Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, or Safari)
  • Adobe Acrobat Reader (free)
  • Webcam, microphone, headset/earbuds, and speaker
  • Microsoft Office (Microsoft 365 is free for currently enrolled ASU students)
  • Reliable broadband internet connection (DSL or cable) to stream videos.

Note: A smartphone, iPad, Chromebook, etc. will not be sufficient for completing your work in ASU Online courses. While you will be able to access course content with mobile devices, you must use a computer for all assignments, quizzes, and virtual labs.

Help

For technical support, use the Help icon in the black global navigation menu in your Canvas course or call the ASU Help Desk at 1+(855) 278-5080. Representatives are available to assist you 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. 

Student Success

To be successful:

  • check the course daily
  • read announcements
  • read and respond to course email messages as needed
  • complete assignments by the due dates specified
  • communicate regularly with your instructor and peers
  • create a study and/or assignment schedule to stay on track
  • access ASU Online Student Resources

Grades and Grade Posting

In this course, your grade is based on the points that you earn. There are 630 possible points, which are listed below. No items are weighted—your grade is based solely on total points received.

All grades will be posted on Canvas at myasucourses.asu.edu. You have seven (7) days after the due date to dispute a grade after the deadline. Do not wait until the end of the semester to check your grades. 

Submitting Assignments

All assignments, unless otherwise announced, MUST be submitted to the designated area of Canvas. Do not submit an assignment via email unless asked to do so.

Assignment due dates follow Arizona Standard time. Click the following link to access the Time Converter to ensure you account for the difference in Time Zones. Note: Arizona does not observe daylight savings time.

Grading Procedure

Grades reflect your performance on assignments and adherence to deadlines. We no longer require some assignments to be uploaded for hand grading.

Late or Missed Assignments

All assignments will be open and available on the first day of class. However, due dates are assigned for “groups” of chapters to help keep you on schedule. You cannot submit assignments after the due date, so please note when those due dates are scheduled and plan accordingly (see the Assignment Schedule at the end of this syllabus). If you experience computer issues during an assignment, you are responsible for documenting the issue as it happens and emailing this to the TA or the instructor ASAP.

Notify the instructor BEFORE an assignment is due if an urgent situation arises and you are unable to submit the assignment on time.

Follow the appropriate University policies to request accommodations for religious practices or to accommodate a missed assignment due to University sanctioned activities.

No “Y” grades will be given for this course.

(No assignment is dropped)

 

SmartBook Readings (14 @ 10 points each)

Total Points Possible

Assignments: The following is a brief description of each assignment, including the point value.

(a)   SmartBook (140 points): SmartBook is a helpful study product. The goal of SmartBook is to help you learn the topics presented in each assignment by asking you a series of questions that adapt to your strengths and weaknesses to guide you through the material you need to learn. Each of the 14 SmartBook activities is worth 10 points. See the Assignment Schedule at the end of this syllabus for chapter due dates.

(b) Interactive Exercises (70 points): For all 14 chapters, you will complete a small set of interactive questions. Each Interactive Exercise is worth 5 points. You can use your textbook or your notes to complete these exercises, but not another person. These exercises are not timed. See the Assignment Schedule at the end of this syllabus for chapter due dates.

(c)   Investigations (140 points): At the end of every chapter in your textbook is a two-page investigation, and you will complete 14 of these by answering questions in Connect. Each investigation is worth ten points. You will need to read and refer to the investigation two-page spread in your textbook while completing the investigation. You can use your textbook and notes when completing these investigations, and you can collaborate with other classmates, but please do your own work. Each investigation requires using most of the information you learned from the chapter to study the geology or the geologic problem of a virtual place, so we suggest doing the Investigation after completing most of the other assignments for that chapter. Investigations are challenging (but fun) because you must reason, based on what you learned from the chapter, how to solve a geologic problem; thus, the answers to Investigation questions are not found directly in the textbook word for word. See the Assignment Schedule at the end of this syllabus for chapter due dates.

(d) Chapter Quizzes (280 points): For each chapter, you will complete a quiz that covers information from the textbook. Each of the 14 quizzes is worth 20 points. You can use your textbook or your notes to answer these quizzes, but not another person. Each quiz has a time limit of 30 minutes, which will not be enough to look up every answer from scratch during a quiz. In other words, you will need to read the textbook before beginning the time-limited online quiz. Use the What-to-Know list as your guide of what to study in preparation for the online quizzes. See the Assignment Schedule at the end of this syllabus for chapter due dates.

Additional Study Material

Although not assigned for grading, a series of movies are available for you to view in order to broaden your knowledge of a number of topics in the textbook. Some movies play by themselves; other movies require you to click forward to the next screen. Additionally, some movies are serious whereas others contain humor. Humor is sometimes hard to convey and preference for humor varies from person to person. If you find you do not appreciate the humor, just ignore it.

Geology Lecture (GLG101) Versus Geology Lab (GLG103)

In order to receive a laboratory science credit, you must also take the laboratory, GLG103. The laboratory is independent of this class in terms of registration and grades. The lecture and lab complement each other by covering different aspects of the same material. You can take GLG103 subsequently to GLG101, but ideally, it should be taken the same semester.

ASU Online Course Policies

View the ASU Online Course Policies

If any other tools are used in this course, links to the accessibility statements will be listed below this sentence.

This is an abbreviated version of the syllabus. The full syllabus (located under the Modules tab) is a statement of intent and serves as an implicit agreement between the instructor and the student. Every effort will be made to avoid changing the course schedule but the possibility exists that unforeseen events will make syllabus changes necessary. Remember to check your ASU email and the course site often.

Use the Modules tab to access the assignments and to read the full syllabus.
