syllabus_body:
GLG 103 Online: Intro to Geology 1: Laboratory

To print: MAC users press "⌘" + "P". PC users press "CTRL" + "P".

Credits: 1     NOTE: For this session, I eliminated two lab exercises and the Top Hat exercises. I opted to line out/gray out the wording in the syllabus rather than delete the wording in case I changed my mind for the next semester.

Prerequisites: None

Instructor: Julia Johnson

Primary email contact: (asu.glg103@gmail.com). Use this email for everyday questions about assignments, grades, course content, and issues with Canvas.

Instructor: Julia Johnson (julia.johnson@asu.edu). Use this email for serious issues, such as health emergencies.

Office Hours: We do not meet face-to-face or Zoom with online students. Most issues can be resolved using email.

This syllabus is an abbreviated version. See the full syllabus by clicking on the Modules tab.

Course Description

This is the accompanying lab for the Introduction to Geology lecture (GLG101). Some lab worksheets will be uploaded for hand grading, such as worksheets that require you to draw your own topographic maps, geologic maps, and cross sections. You will also complete a virtual field trip as well as research the geology of your hometown (or favorite location) and write a one-page summary.

Course Learning Outcomes

At the completion of this course, students will be able to:

  1. Become familiar with the factors and processes that shape natural landscapes.
  2. Interpret the topography of an area from a topographic map and locate features on such a map.
  3. Observe and identify common minerals and rocks and interpret how they formed.
  4. Reconstruct a series of geologic events using the clues contained in a landscape.
  5. Produce a simple geologic map of an area and construct a geologic cross section using the geologic map and topography.
  6. Site the location of natural resources and geologic hazards.
  7. Understand how the geology is expressed in the landscapes of northern, central, and southern Arizona.
  8. Use geologic information to summarize the geologic history of an area.

Lab Manual

Observing and Interpreting Geology – Manual for Online Introductory Geology Laboratory, GLG103 Online Edition, by Johnson, J.K., and Reynolds, S.J. This laboratory manual is required as it contains instructions, information, and worksheets, a few of which you will complete and deliver electronically. Top Hat hosts the online lab manual, and you can register to use the lab manual (~$45) by using the link below.

Relation to GLG101

The laboratory course, GLG 103, is administered separately from the lecture course, GLG 101. Grades are determined independently for each course and not combined into one grade. Both GLG101 and GLG103 must be taken to secure SQ or SG credit. These courses cover different types of material and can be taken during different sessions.

Online Activity 

The design of this online lab course is such that you have 14 modules to complete in a single online session. Thus, this course has deadlines to help you stay on track. Please see the due dates in this syllabus. You will use the online lab manual for instructions and content as there are no prerecorded videos. You will not be allowed to complete exercises or modules after a due date, nor will you be allowed to complete modules after the session ends.  You should plan on approximately two hours of work per lab.

Assignment Schedule

All the assignments are open on the first day of classes so you may work at your own place, but there are five specific due dates for which you must complete certain assignments (due on the date indicated at 11:59 p.m.) so that you stay on track. Grading

Grades are assigned based on points you earn by completing (1) the lab modules, (2) quizzes, (3) worksheets at the end of each lab, (4) worksheets on the geology of your hometown, and (5) worksheets on Tempe Butte. There are no hour exams and no final. Completing the lab worksheets and answering corresponding questions on Canvas accounts for most of the total points. The point distributions and typical letter-grade assignments for the total points earned are listed below.

  • Top Hat exercises are worth ten points each. Lab modules are worth 40 points, except for the Hometown Geology lab and the Tempe Butte lab, as described below. No exercise, lab, or quiz score will be dropped. Some worksheets will be delivered electronically for grading. Grades for the exercises, labs, and the quizzes will be available on Canvas. The “Virtual Field Trip to Tempe Butte” lab is worth 60 points, to be assigned based on your completed geologic map, cross-section, field notes, and geologic history. The “Hometown Geology” lab is worth 80 points, to be assigned based on a worksheet you complete on the geology of your hometown (or another place of interest), the notes you took while examining maps, and a short, typed write up.
  • Delivery of Paper-Based Activities: For most modules, you will be able to complete all the required activities via the internet, guided by questions on worksheets in the lab manual. For some modules, however, you are required to complete the activities on a worksheet in the lab manual. You will send a digital image of these paper worksheets to the instructor, capturing the image via one of the following methods: (1) scan the worksheet on a scanner or all-in-one printer connected to your computer; or (2) photograph the worksheet using a digital camera or a camera on your cell phone or mp3 player. You can then deliver this digital image to your instructor from the “submit” link on Canvas, as an email attachment, or sent directly from your phone. Many students no longer have access to a printer, so you may download the worksheet and use a stylus or drawing program to complete these exercises. Please be as accurate as possible when using these tools.
  • Your grade is based on the points that you earn. No items are weighted--your grade is based solely on total points received. Note that ASU does not allow C-, D+, or D- grades.

name: Global Leadership Academy Fall 2021
syllabus_body:
Global Leadership Academy - Fall 2021

Syllabus

 

Purpose: 

The Global Leadership Academy (GLA) develops students into globally engaged leaders. This fall, the Academy will focus on the practical application of leadership skills while building a theoretical understanding of leadership in a global context.  Participants will select from a variety of workshops, with topics ranging from; event coordination, service based leadership, effective communication, professional development and networking, among others. 

 

Structure: 

Participants will attend the four mandatory sessions: 

  • GLA Kickoff Celebration
  • The 5 Essential Civic Skills and Behaviors
  • Conflict Management
  • Leveraging your GLA Certificate

There will be eight other workshops that students can choose from.  Participants will need to attend at least four optional workshops to earn their certificate.  Each workshop will start with a check-in QR code to track attendance.

  • Success@ASU Conference
  • Interviewing Skills
  • Rapid Resume Review
  • LinkedIn 101
  • Every Sun Devil a Changemaker
  • Creating a Safe and Caring Community
  • The Importance of A Mentorship Network
  • Bystander Empowerment
  • Days of Service

 

Optional Service Project and Conference Funding

There are several college leadership conferences that happen every year. For GLA participants interested in having a conference experience, GLA will provide up to $500 in funding.  In order to earn this funding, participants will lead a service project during the semester. To learn more about this opportunity and how to earn conference funding, please email  Halie.Cousineau@asu.edu or  jtroy3@asu.edu to set up an appointment. 

 

Slack conversations and Social Networking

Participants will be added to the GLA Fall 2021 ASU Slack Channel.  After each workshop, participants are encouraged to engage in conversations with peers on Slack. We also encourage participants to get to know each other and spend time building your leadership networks.

name: HW0-SectionJ
syllabus_body:
You are NOW starting your college education, and we are happy to welcome you to the Ira A. Fulton Schools of Engineering (FSE) at Arizona State University (ASU).

You have been automatically enrolled to this Canvas course, ASU101 Homework 0 - Forging Your Success.  We have designed this course as a series of modules to ease your transition to college and help you to be successful. The assignments in these modules will help you to:

  • transition into college and Fulton Schools mindset at ASU,
  • connect with faculty and upper-level students to obtain information and learn best practices that are relevant for us at Fulton School of Engineering in all our different academic programs,
  • learn about all the resources that ASU and Fulton School of Engineering have to help you to succeed,
  • learn about technology platforms we use at ASU,
  • get immersed in the entrepreneurial mindset, which is a core part of our academic signature.

 

ASU101 Homework 0 modules are to be completed during the Summer break (June - August 2021) before your first semester (Fall 2021). These modules and its assignments are the starting point for future assignments you will complete during your first semester (Fall 2021) as part of your ASU101 course. These modules are:

    • Explore and learn about ASU and FSE! Complete a scavenger hunt and learn more about the resources that ASU and FSE offer you to enrich and enhance your academic career. 
    • Been there, done that! Ask me! What would you ask to upper-level students and faculty members about their experiences and recommendation to be a FSE successful student?
    • College time! Plan to succeed! A module where you will define strategies to tackle the challenges you are facing while starting your college career.

 

Beside these activities, we highly recommend you to register to the E2 experience, an immersive experience where you will get to know your classmates while you practice teamwork and problem-solving skills. You will meet students in your major, who are taking your same classes, and learn skills and pro-tips from your C2 peer mentor. 

 

Instructors of this course

We are a team of instructors working to support you, please feel free to contact us if you have any questions about this activity, just click in our names below.

  • Helen Chavez
  • Tami Coronella
  • Lindsey Dickerson

 

Let’s start!

For more instructions on how to navigate this Canvas course, its modules, and assignments, you can check out this video:

If you want more details on what is included in this course and how to use it, you want to check the Readme First module.

Once you are familiar with this Canvas course and its organization, your next step is to visit the Modules tab on the left-hand side, where you will find the detailed content for each module listed above, including the information and instructions you need to complete each module.
